questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to the Little's area?

choices.text: Keisselbach's plexus is present in the Little's area.
It is situated at the postero-inferior part of the nasal septum.
Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here.

questions.solution:
The correct statement among the following is that Keisselbach's plexus is present in the Little's area.

Little’s area, situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults. 90% of bleeds arise from Little's area, where the Kiesselbach plexus is situated on the nasal septum. 

Kiesselbach’s plexus:

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum (Little's area) to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus.

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of the superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine

questions.text: Identify the investigation shown below.
questions.solution:
The investigation shown above is enteroclysis.

Enteroclysis is a barium study in which the contrast agent is put directly into the duodenum through a nasogastric tube.

Continued infusion of 500 to 1000 mL of thin barium sulfate and methylcellulose suspension is done and then viewed continuously with the use of either fluoroscopy or radiographs taken at frequent intervals. This technique is a double-contrast procedure that allows detailed imaging of the entire small intestine.

Enteroclysis has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumors (Particularly for tumors located in the distal small bowel) and is the investigation of choice in low-grade, intermittent small bowel obstruction.

Advantages of enteroclysis:

  • The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel, bypassing the regulatory action of the pylorus.
  • The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state, allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, the following can be visualized:
    • Mild strictures
    • Small sinus tracts and fistulas
    • Minimal extrinsic compressions
    • Skip lesions
    • Proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
  • The examination can be completed in 15–30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Other options:

Option B: Barium meal assesses the stomach and duodenum (95% BaSO4 is used). Used in ulcers, small fleshy lumps (polyps), and tumours.

Option C: Barium meal follow-through is used to assess the small intestine (50% BaSO4 is used). It is performed following a barium meal examination where X-rays are taken 10-15 minutes after barium intake. This allows time for the barium to reach the small intestine. 

Option D: Barium swallow is used to assess the pharynx, oesophagus, and stomach. (Barium paste is used). They are used in hiatus hernias, tumours, reflux from the stomach, and disorders of swallowing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of hypertension for the past 10 years presents with dyspnoea and chest pain. On examination, he is found to have collapsing pulse and Austin Flint murmur. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of a collapsing pulse are suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Austin Flint murmur further supports the diagnosis of aortic regurgitation.

Collapsing pulse/Watson’s water hammer pulse is a rapidly rising pulse, which collapses suddenly as arterial pressure falls rapidly, during late systole and diastole. It is also called Corrigan's pulse.

The various causes of the collapsing pulse are described below:

  • Physiologically, it can be present in fever and pregnancy. This is attributed to the combination of increased cardiac output and the reduction in systemic vascular resistance. 
  • Cardiac lesions such as aortic regurgitation, patent ductus arteriosus, systolic hypertension, marked bradycardia, aneurysm of sinus of Valsalva.
  • High-output states such as anaemia, cor pulmonale, thyrotoxicosis, arteriovenous fistula, Paget's disease, beriberi, and liver cirrhosis (secondary to chronic alcoholism).

Austin Flint murmur is a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur heard in chronic severe AR. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Other options:

Option B: Left-sided heart failure leads to pulmonary congestion, causing symptoms like dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. It results from conditions like hypertension, ischemic heart disease, or cardiomyopathy, impairing the heart’s ability to pump blood effectively.

Option C: Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve, leading to obstructed blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta. It commonly presents with symptoms like chest pain, syncope, and dyspnea on exertion.

Option D: Co-existing aortic stenosis and regurgitation involves both obstruction to blood flow and backflow of blood into the left ventricle, leading to increased cardiac workload. This condition can cause symptoms like dyspnea, angina, and heart failure, requiring careful management based on severity.

questions.text: Patient with history of trauma came to the emergency department. Which of the following is not a part of a primary survey?

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.solution:
Taking CT scan of the patient is not a part of a primary survey. It is a part of a secondary survey.

Primary survey is used to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support):

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood – FBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen,glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG
  • Two wide-bore 18G cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the cervical spine and chest
  • Lateral cervical spine, chest AP view and pelvis AP view is done when necessary.
  • Other more specialised forms of imaging, such as ultrasound,computerised tomography, angiography and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and onlywhen the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has ideas of grandiosity. He thinks himself to be very successful and correct all the time and cannot tolerate if someone criticises him. What is the type of personality disorder?
questions.solution:
The above clinical case scenario is suggestive of narcissistic personality disorder.

 Narcissistic personality disorder is included under cluster B personality disorder.

Cluster B personality disorder / dramatic, emotional, and erratic group:

Patients with these personality disorders characteristically have chaotic lives, emotions, and relationships.

  • Borderline personalities are impulsive, unpredictable, angry, temperamental, unstable in relationships, compulsively interpersonal, and self-damaging with regard to sex, money, and substance use.
  • Histrionic personalities are attention seeking, exhibitionistic, seductive, self-indulgent, exhibit exaggerated expressions of emotions, and overconcerned with physical appearance.
  • Narcissistic personalities tend to be hypersensitive to criticism, exploitative of others, egocentric with an inflated sense of self-importance, feel entitled to special treatment, and demand constant attention.
  • Antisocial personalities are truant, lie, steal, start fights, break rules, are unable to sustain work or school and shirk everyday responsibilities.

questions.text: A college-going student presents to you with rapidly increasing power in his glasses due to progressive myopia. On asking the patient to look down you notice the following sign. The ophthalmic examination in this condition usually reveals all the following additional signs except
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing Munson's sign are suggestive of keratoconus. In keratoconus, Vogt's striae are seen (not Haab's striae).

Haab’s striae are tears and breaks in Descemet's membrane, as seen in congenital glaucoma. 

The signs seen in keratoconus are:

Keratoconus is a progressive disorder and occurs due to central/paracentral thinning of the corneal stroma. This results in apical protrusion of the cornea and irregular astigmatism. Patients complain of defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism despite full correction with glasses.

The signs seen in keratoconus include:

  • Munson's sign is the localized bulging of the lower eyelid when the patient is looking downwards.
  • Using distant direct ophthalmoscopy a well-delineated oil droplet reflex can be elicited. It is an annular black shadow that separates the central and peripheral areas of the cornea. 
  • Fleischer's rings are epithelial iron deposits that are best seen with a cobalt blue filter during slit-lamp examination. 
  • Vogt striae are vertical deep stromal lines seen using a slit-lamp.
  • The scissoring/yawning reflex can be elicited using a retinoscopy. It occurs when two bands of a light beam reflexed from the retina move like the blades of a pair of scissors.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with confusion and dyspnea; he was diagnosed with pneumonia. His blood pressure is 128/76 mmHg, and his respiratory rate is 32 breaths/min. His blood urea level is 10 mmol/L. What would be the best management plan for him?

choices.text: Treat as an outpatient with supportive therapy.
Treat as an outpatient with antibiotics.
Admit to the intensive care unit.

questions.solution:
This patient with pneumonia should be admitted to ICU as his CURB-65 score is 4.

CURB-65 criteria are used to assess the severity of illness in a case of pneumonia, especially community-acquired pneumonia.

It includes 5 variables:

  1. C - Confusion 
  2. U - Urea >7mmol/L
  3. R - Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  4. B - Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg
  5. 65 - Age ≥65 years
  • Patients with scores of 0 are considered as low risk and home treatment can be considered.
  • Patients with a score of 1- 2 will require short inpatient hospitalization or closely supervised outpatient treatment
  • Patients with scores of 3-5 have severe pneumonia. It will require hospitalization and admission to the intensive care unit.

The Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI) is another index to assess the severity of illness and the risk of mortality in the case of pneumonia.
It includes 20 variables and depending on the score, patients are assigned to one of the 5 classes:

  • Class, I, II, III - at low risk of death and can be treated on an outpatient basis
  • Class IV & V - require hospitalization

questions.text: A patient with end-stage renal disease from diabetic nephropathy is a candidate for renal transplant. A live kidney donor has been identified. Identify the correct statement about renal transplant in this scenario.

choices.text: The donor’s right kidney is preferred for transplant
Nephrectomy of recipient's damaged kidneys is indicated here
The renal vein is anastomosed to the internal iliac vein
The iliac fossa is the ideal site for transplantation

questions.solution:
In this scenario, for the renal transplant from a live kidney donor, the iliac fossa is the ideal site for transplantation in the recipient.

Kidney transplantation is indicated in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD). It is associated with better outcomes and better life expectancy when compared to hemodialysis. The leading causes of ESRD necessitating renal transplant include diabetic nephropathy, hypertension, and chronic glomerulonephritis. 

Nephrectomy of damaged kidneys in the recipient for the causes above is not indicated (option B).  However, nephrectomy is indicated in cases of chronic pyelonephritis, large polycystic kidneys, significant vesicoureteral reflux, or uncontrollable renovascular hypertension.

The donor's left kidney is preferred for transplant because of a longer vascular pedicle (option A). The donor kidney is transplanted into one of the recipient's iliac fossae. This is because of the proximity of the iliac fossae to the bladder and iliac vessels. 

The transplant renal vein is anastomosed to the external or common iliac vein (option C). The transplant renal artery is anastomosed preferably to the internal iliac artery for live donors. However, it can also be anastomosed to the external or common iliac artery. After revascularisation of the transplanted kidney, the ureter is then anastomosed to the bladder.

questions.text: A patient comes with a complaint of vertigo in a certain head position. She denies any ear fullness or hearing loss. A Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis and an Epley's maneuver is performed to treat her condition. The symptoms are relieved due to the repositioning of otoconial debris from?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with vertigo and a positive Dix-Hallpike test is suggestive of benign positional paroxysmal vertigo (BPPV). The otoconial debris are repositioned from the posterior semicircular canal to the utricle to relieve the symptoms of BPPV.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. 

A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. In up to 90 percent of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley's maneuver on the affected side.

The Epley's maneuver consists of five positions:

Position 1 Head turned 45°  to lie down in a head-hanging position
Position 2 Head turned with
affected ear up		 -
Position 3 The whole body and head rotated away from the affected ear in a face-down position  
Position 4 Head still turned to unaffected side by 45° Brought to sitting position
Position 5 Head turned forward with chin brought down 20° -

questions.text:
Match the following radiograph images with their views.
  1. Submentovertical view
  2. Caldwell view
  3. Water's view
  4. Towne's view
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a.

1 c. Water's view
2 b. Caldwell view
3 d. Towne's view
4 a. Submentovertical view

Waters' view (also known as the Occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view, where an X-ray beam is angled at 37° to the orbitomeatal line. The rays are passed from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.

Structures observed:

  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (through open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone

Caldwell's view (also known as the occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is a radiographic view of the skull, where the X-ray plate is angled at 15° to the orbito-meatal line. The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  • It is commonly used to get a better view of frontal sinuses.

Structures seen are: 

  • Frontal sinuses 
  • Ethmoid sinuses
  • Maxillary sinuses
  • Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone
  • Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)

The image below shows Caldwell's view 

Towne's view: 

It is taken with the patient in the supine position and lying on his back with the chin often depressed into the neck. The X-ray camera is angled at 30 degrees towards the feet so that the rays enter the head at the level of the hairline.

  • This is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.
  • Bilateral petrous pyramids are visible in this view and hence can be compared.
Structures seen are:
  • Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
  • Mastoid antrum.
  • Internal auditory canal.
  • Tympanic cavity.
  • Cochlea.
  • External auditory canal.

The image below shows Towne's view 

Submentovertical view (also known as the basal view or Hirtz view) is taken with vertex near the film and X-ray beam projected at right angles to the film from the submental area.

 Structures seen are:
  • Sphenoid, posterior ethmoid, and maxillary sinuses (seen best in that order).
  • Zygoma.
  • Zygomatic arch.
  • Mandible along with coronoid and condyloid processes.
  • External auditory canal.
  • Middle ear cleft, i.e. mastoid cells, middle ear, and eustachian tube.
  • Internal auditory canal.

questions.text: A 35-year-old housewife with constipation-predominant irritable bowel syndrome presents with worsening abdominal pain and bloating. Which of the following drugs can be prescribed to her?
questions.solution:
Lubiprostone is used in the treatment of constipation-predominant IBS and can be prescribed to this patient.

Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator that promotes the secretion of water and chloride into the bowel and improves bowel movements.

Loperamide, alosetron, and cholestyramine resin are used in the treatment of diarrhoea-predominant IBS.

questions.text: A patient is shifted for emergency laparotomy for the management of intraabdominal hemorrhage, following a road traffic accident. Intraoperatively, you find an active hemorrhage from grade 4 liver laceration. Which of the following techniques will you use to decrease bleeding from the liver?
questions.solution:
Pringle's maneuver can be performed to decrease the active hemorrhage from the liver in a liver laceration. It is done by applying pressure on the portal triad at the Foramen of Winslow. The pressure can be applied either digitally or with the use of a soft clamp. 

4 P's in the management of liver injuries are: 

  • Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration
  • Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad
  • Plug the defects with silicon tubes
  • Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding

questions.text: A 53-year-old man is admitted with a history of cerebrovascular accident 2 days ago. The patient is drowsy with minimal response. CT picture is shown in the figure. What will be your next line of management?
questions.solution:
Patient's CT shows significant edema in the middle cerebral artery (MCA) territory (at least >50%), as indicated in the image below. In such cases, brain herniation is impending, and the patient needs to be referred for decompressive neurosurgery.

Medical management of brain edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) may not be successful when significant swelling occurs in the cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere.

Guidelines for urgent decompression (STATE criteria):

  • Score: GCS < 8
  • Time: < 48h
  • Age: < 60 yrs
  • Territory infarct: > 150 cm3 or > 50% MCA territory
  • Expectancy of life is high

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

Intracranial hypertension is pressure within the cranium above normal. Normal range of ICP is 5-15mm Hg. Levels above 20-25mm Hg are usually treated. 

Causes: Intracranial haemorrhage, brain tumors, head injury, meningitis, brain abscess, etc. 

Symptoms of raised ICT

  • Cushing’s triad – hypertension, bradycardia and respiratory depression
  • Headache, visual blurring due to papilloedema and abducent nerve palsy 
  • Focal symptoms may arise due to the local effects in patients with mass lesions or due to herniation.
  • Seizures
  • Stroke

Investigations

  • CT brain or MRI brain with gadolinium to rule out ICSOL 
  • Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in the presence of raised ICT due to the risk of coning.
  • Papilledema (as an indicator of ICT) should be ruled out before lumbar puncture.

Treatment

  • Dexamethasone
  • Ventriculotomy to remove CSF or ventriculoperitoneal shunt
  • Decompressive craniectomy
  • Surgical resection of ICSOL – by craniotomy or stereotactic radiosurgery
  • Whole brain radiation for multiple metastases causing raised ICT

questions.text: A ligament is marked in red in the given image below. According to the Denis three-column concept of spinal stability, the given ligament comes under which column?
questions.solution:
The given ligament marked in red is the posterior longitudinal ligament. It is a component of the middle column.

Denis three-column concept of spinal stability: This was used to describe the classification of spinal injuries.

    • Anterior column:
    • Anterior half of the vertebral body
    • Anterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Anterior longitudinal ligament
  • Middle column:
    • Posterior half of the vertebral body
    • Posterior part of the intervertebral disc
    • Posterior longitudinal ligament
  • Posterior column
    • Pedicles
    • Facet joints
    • Posterior bony arch
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Supraspinous ligament

The fractures involving the middle column and at least one other column are regarded as unstable injuries i.e. there is a significant risk of displacement of the vertebral components, leading to damage of the neural tissues.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with complaints of daydreaming in the class as reported by his teacher. Examination revealed that the child had episodes of sudden brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control, which was induced by hyperventilation.  Such episodes lasted for a few seconds, and there was no post-ictal confusion. The child is most likely suffering from
questions.solution:
Sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in Absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

The seizures may occur about 100 times a day, and the child is unaware. The seizures are so subtle, that may go unrecognized by parents. Most common complaints include "daydreaming" and a decline in school performance recognized by a teacher. The seizures can be provoked by hyperventilation.

EEG shows generalized symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

Other options:

Option A: Syncope is defined as transient, self-limited loss of consciousness due to a sudden decrease in cerebral blood flow. There is a loss of postural control, and patients may faint.

Option B: Myoclonic seizures have preserved consciousness. They involve a sudden brief jerking movement involving the entire body or a part of it.

Option C: Atonic seizures are characterized by a sudden loss of postural control.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding indirect ophthalmoscopy?

choices.text: The image produced is erect and real
Condensor needs to be kept very close to the eye

questions.solution:
An indirect ophthalmoscope produces an inverted real image of 3 to 5 times magnification.

Advantages of the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope are:

  • Visualization through hazy media is possible due to strong in built illumination system.
  • Field of view is much larger than direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Examination of peripheral retina up to ora serrata is possible.

questions.text: A young man is incidentally found to have a pseudocyst of the pancreas on abdominal ultrasound. Past history is notable for one episode of acute pancreatitis. An aspirate from the cyst is likely to show:

choices.text: Low amylase levels and high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
Low amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
High amylase levels and high carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels
High amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels

questions.solution:
An aspirate from a pancreatic pseudocyst is likely to show high amylase levels and low carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels. It is also associated with the absence of mucin.

Pancreatic pseudocysts are non-necrotic fluid-filled oval or round collections encapsulated in a relatively thick wall. They develop 4 weeks after acute pancreatitis and are frequently found on imaging follow-up of pancreatitis. They may be asymptomatic or become large enough to cause mass effects such as gastric outlet obstruction, bowel obstruction, hydronephrosis, and biliary obstruction.

The capsule of a pseudocyst is composed of collagen and granulation tissue, and it is not lined by epithelium. It presents with abdominal pain and epigastric mass. CT is usually done in the evaluation of pancreatic pseudocysts.

Observation is the preferred treatment in cases where the size of the pseudocyst is less than 6 cm and arises from the tail of the pancreas. Interventions are required when it is complicated with infection, large size causing mass effect, diameter increasing in size or greater than 6 cm, recurrence following previous resection.

Treatment includes:

  • Open surgical debridement
  • Cystenterostomy
  • Endoscopic cyst-gastrostomy
  • Percutaneous drainage
  • Octreotide infusion (decreases the amount of pancreatic secretions)

Based on the revised Atlanta classification, peripancreatic fluid, and their collections can be classified into 4 different types based on their morphology and time of presentation:

  • Interstitial edematous pancreatitis (IEP):
    • APFC- acute peripancreatic fluid collection. Non-necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • Pancreatic pseudocyst- non-necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)
  • Necrotizing pancreatitis:
    • ANC- acute necrotic collection. Necrotic fluid collection presenting within 4 weeks 
    • WON- walled-off necrosis. Necrotic fluid collection when it undergoes encapsulation (after 4 weeks)

Collections that contain non-liquefied material or show the presence of gas, are more likely to be infected.

Note: High levels of CEA is suggestive of mucinous neoplasm.

questions.text: A 37 year old male patient comes to the clinic with complaints of weakness, restlessness, and chest pain. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg, his heart sounds are muffled and his neck veins are distended. What is the typical JVP finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention are the three principal features of cardiac tamponade. This is called Beck’s triad, and the typical JVP finding here is absent y descent.

JVP will have a prominent 'x' (early systolic) descent but an absent 'y' (early diastolic) descent because of the limited or absent early diastolic filling of the ventricle. JVP is almost always elevated in cardiac tamponade and may be associated with venous distention in the forehead and scalp. There may be reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves in cardiac tamponade.

Other options:

Option A: Absent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) is seen in atrial fibrillation due to the loss of organized atrial contraction. This results in a continuous venous flow without the characteristic atrial contraction wave.

Option B: A prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) is seen in conditions with increased right atrial pressure, such as pulmonary hypertension or tricuspid stenosis. It occurs due to forceful right atrial contraction against a resistant right ventricle.

Option C: A rapid 'y' descent in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) is seen in conditions with rapid right atrial emptying, such as constrictive pericarditis or severe tricuspid regurgitation. It reflects an abrupt drop in right atrial pressure during early ventricular filling.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl who was diagnosed with SLE at 13 years of age is now refractory to standard treatment. She is prescribed a monoclonal antibody which is an anti-B-cell activator. Which of the following drugs is she prescribed?
questions.solution:
Belimumab is a monoclonal antibody that is an anti-B-cell activator. It is used in the management of lupus refractory to standard treatment. 

Belimumab inhibits the soluble form of a B cell survival factor (known as BLyS or BAFF) which promotes the formation of memory B cells and autoantibodies. It is used in combination with either cyclophosphamide or MMF in patients with lupus nephritis who do not show a response to initial therapy with steroids.

Other options:

Option A: Rozanolixizumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that has been recently FDA-approved for the treatment of myasthenia gravis.

Option C: Daclizumab is an IL2R antagonist that binds to CD25 and is used in the relapsing type of multiple sclerosis.

Option D: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF alpha agent used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: All are ocular manifestations of dengue except ________.
questions.solution:
Cataract is not an ocular manifestation of dengue.

Potential pathogenic mechanisms include a direct viral effect on the eye, an immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements.

Ocular manifestations of dengue:

  • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, often around the time of the platelet nadir.
  • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis
  • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice for 15 days. He has clay-colored stools and hepatomegaly. Ultrasound is performed and shown below. What is the name of the ultrasound finding?
questions.solution:
The newborn with persistent jaundice for more than 14 days, clay-coloured stool, and hepatomegaly is likely to have biliary atresia. The ultrasound confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating the triangular cord sign. 

The triangular cord sign represents the cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein. This density is echogenic and represents the fibrous remains of the porta hepatis. A ≥ 4 mm thickness of the echogenic anterior wall of the right portal vein (EARPV) measured on a longitudinal ultrasound scan, strongly suggests biliary atresia.

Biliary atresia is a rare, life-threatening condition in newborns where the bile ducts inside or outside the liver are blocked or absent, preventing bile flow from the liver to the intestine. This leads to bile buildup, liver damage, and eventually cirrhosis if untreated. The exact cause is unknown, but it may involve genetic and environmental factors. Symptoms include jaundice, pale stools, dark urine, and an enlarged liver. Diagnosis involves blood tests, imaging, and sometimes a liver biopsy. The primary treatment is the Kasai procedure, which can restore bile flow, but many children eventually require a liver transplant.

Other options: 

Option A: The falciform ligament sign is seen in the case of pneumoperitoneum. Here, the air outlines the appearance of the falciform ligament as seen in the X-ray below. 

Option C: Double bubble sign occurs due to dilated stomach and duodenum in duodenal atresia. It is seen in X-rays and ultrasound. The following image depicts the double bubble sign. 

Option D: Target sign is seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. This is due to hypertrophied hypoechoic muscle surrounding echogenic mucosa. The following ultrasound image shows target sign.

questions.text: Among the following, the first muscle to be affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis is ______.
questions.solution:
The first muscle to be affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis is the lateral rectus.

Ophthalmoplegia in cavernous sinus thrombosis occurs in the following sequence:

  • 6th nerve palsy (lateral rectus palsy) occurring first of all as it passes through the cavernous sinus. As a result, patients often present with an inability to abduct the eye.
  • 3rd and 4th nerves are involved later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following best measures ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Antimullerian Hormone (AMH), secreted by the granulosa cells, is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the cycle.

AMH is secreted by the Sertoli cells in the testis and granulosa cells in the ovary. In males, it inhibits the development of the Müllerian system and its absence can result in hermaphroditism. In the female, it helps in follicular development and oocyte maturation. The estimation of serum AMH is used in the study of ovarian reserve in an infertile woman and a woman with secondary amenorrhoea. The levels of AMH vary minimally across the cycle and they strongly correlate with the number of ovarian primordial follicles. This makes AMH is the best predictor for measuring ovarian reserve. AMH levels can be affected by the use of oral contraceptives and tobacco smoking.

Values and interpretation:

  • Normal value: 2–6.8 ng/mL
  • Poor ovarian reserve : <1 ng/mL
  • PCOD and hyperstimulation syndrome: >10 ng/mL

Tests for ovarian reserve: Ovarian reserve means the capacity of the ovary to produce eggs. The other indicators include:

  • FSH levels are measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle) - High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted (FSH is highest in postmenopausal women). FSH (values >25mIU/ml) levels are higher than normal in women with a reduced ovarian reserve and ovarian hypofunction. 
  • Serum oestradiol values on day 3 of the cycle. Serum oestradiol <75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • LH - values <10 IU/L indicates poor reserve
  • Antral follicular count - counts less than 4–5 on days 2–5 denotes poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B - values <40 pg/mL indicates poor reserve

questions.text: A sexually active young woman presents with abdominal pain in her left lower abdomen. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago and she has regular monthly menstrual cycles. Vitals are normal. What could be the cause of the pain?
questions.solution:
This patient with pain 2 weeks after her last menstrual cycle with stable vitals most likely has pain due to Mittelschmerz syndrome. Follicular rupture is the cause of mittelschmerz.

Mittelschmerz, or ovulation pain, is a mid-cycle ache that is usually intense but can sometimes occasionally be mild for several hours. It usually occurs during the LH peak and is caused by the rupture of a Graffian follicle.

It occurs due to the contractions of the ovarian perifollicular smooth muscles which is mediated through PGF2a. Treatment is with NSAIDs.

Other options : 

Option A: PID (Pelvic inflammatory disease) presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge associated with cervical motion tenderness.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancies usually rupture after 4-6 weeks of gestation and patients may have hypotension due to bleeding into the abdominal cavity. This patient has stable vitals. 

Option D: Salpingitis isthmica nodosa is an inflammation of the fallopian tube, marked by nodular thickening in its isthmic segment. This thickening results from the proliferation of smooth muscle and diverticula in the tubal epithelium. It commonly affects both fallopian tubes and increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the audiology clinic with complaints of hearing difficulty in one of her ears. She reports a gradual onset of hearing loss over the past few months. An audiogram is obtained and presented below. Interpret the given audiogram:
questions.solution:
The audiogram indicates abnormalities in both bone conduction (BC) and air conduction (AC) thresholds in the left ear. The blue colour indicates the left ear, and the symbols indicate the thresholds for BC and AC. In both cases, the thresholds are above the normal range (BC >25 dB and AC >15 dB), suggesting sensorineural hearing loss.

Additionally, there is an air-bone gap present, indicating a difference between the AC and BC thresholds, which implies conductive hearing loss. Therefore, based on the combination of sensorineural and conductive components, the interpretation is left mixed hearing loss

Interpretation:

  • Blue color indicates left ear.
  • › indicates BC (Bone Conduction) and threshold is >25 dB. Hence BC is abnormal → sensorineural pathway is abnormal.
  • × indicates AC (Air Conduction) and threshold is >15 dB. Hence AC is abnormal.
  • Both AC and BC are abnormal. It indicates sensorineural hearing loss.
  • In addition, Air-Bone gap is present which implies conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence interpreted as left mixed hearing loss.

questions.text: After a road traffic accident, an old man experienced sudden blurring of vision and floaters in his right eye. What would be the ideal investigation of choice for the suspected vitreous hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for vitreous hemorrhage is an ultrasound B-scan.

B-scan ultrasonography in unclotted vitreous hemorrhage generally shows a uniform appearance, and once cellular aggregates develop, small particulate echoes become visible.

USG B can also be used to assess posterior segment in the case of opaque media, and study intraocular tumors, orbital tumors, and other mass lesions. 

Vitreous hemorrhage has a variable presentation depending on the severity of the hemorrhage. The mild hemorrhage causes sudden onset floaters and diffuse blurring of vision, but may not affect visual acuity, whilst a dense bleed may result in sudden painless loss of vision.

Causes

  • Acute posterior vitreous detachment associated either with a retinal tear or avulsion of a peripheral vessel
  • Proliferative retinopathy
    • Diabetic
    • Retinal vein occlusion
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Eales disease
    • Vasculitis
  • Miscellaneous retinal disorders
    • Macroaneurysm
    • Telangiectasia
    • Capillary hemangioma
  • Trauma
  • Systemic
    • Bleeding disorders
    • Terson syndrome

Treatment is dictated by severity and cause, but an increasingly low threshold is being adopted for early vitrectomy.

Terson syndrome
Terson syndrome refers to the combination of intraocular and subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to aneurysmal rupture, most commonly arising from the anterior communicating artery.

Other options: 

Option A - Optical coherence tomography is used to provide cross-sectional or tomographic images of tissues of less than 10um axial resolution using light waves. It is used to image the anterior chamber angle, trabeculotomy blebs, tumors and cysts of the iris and ciliary body, macular disorders, diagnose glaucoma and in pachymetry. 

Option B - Ultrasound A-scan produces a unidimensional image. It is used to measure axial length, anterior chamber depth, and thickness of intraocular masses. 

Option D - Electroretinography records changes in the resting potential of the eye that are induced by flashes of light. It is used to evaluate retinal disorders, function, especially in cases where fundal examination is not possible.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented to the clinic with the skin lesions as shown in the image. On examination, body temperature is 38.5 degrees Celsius, ESR and ASLO titers are elevated. What is true about the finding shown in the image below?

choices.text: Generally occurs in patients with carditis

questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of rheumatic fever and the skin finding shown in the image is erythema marginatum. It generally occurs in patients with carditis. 

Important features of erythema marginatum are:

  • It is a pink, non-pruritic rash(Option A) that generally occurs on the upper part of the arms or trunk but not on the fac(Option B).
  • It extends from the centre with an irregular serpiginous border. As the size of the rash increases, the centre of the rash returns to normal, while the borders remain pink. Hence it is named “erythema marginatum.”
  • The rash may also become more prominent after a hot shower(Option C).

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: A 54 year old came to casualty with history of massive hemoptypsis. His routine investigation chest X-ray was normal. Which of the following you will not do to prevent hemoptypsis?
questions.solution:
Procoagulant drugs like vasopressin are indicated only if:

  • There is an abnormal coagulation profile.
  • No contraindications to the drug are present.

Massive hemoptysis is generally defined as expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-h period.

Treatment priorities in the management of massive hemoptysis:

  • Achieve respiratory stabilization and prevent asphyxiation.
  • Localize the bleeding site.
    • Bronchoscopy: flexible / rigid
  • Control the hemorrhage.
    • Endobronchially with laser or bronchial occlusion
    • Endovascularly with bronchial and/or pulmonary artery embolization
    • Surgically with resection of the involved lobe
  • Determine the cause.
  • Definitively prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Ms. Kamala comes to the clinic with complaints of pain in the lateral aspect of the right breast for the past 5 days. On examination, the following finding is noted under her breast. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Mondor's disease. The image shows the presence of a subcutaneous cord and a narrow shallow groove along the side of the cord.

Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. The most commonly involved vein is the lateral thoracic vein.

Patients usually present with pain along the lateral chest wall and a tender, firm cord below the breast.

It is a benign condition and gets resolved on its own within 4-6 weeks. Warm compresses and anti-inflammatory medicines can be used to reduce pain. If the symptoms persist despite medications, the affected segment of the vein can be excised.

Tietze’s syndrome (option A) is a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Zuska disease (option B) is the subcutaneous abscess of the breast tissue beneath the areola of the nipple. It is also called a subareolar abscess.

Stewart–Treves Syndrome (option D) is characterized by lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a loss of appetite and increasing fatigue for the last few weeks. The following abnormality is noted on examination. Identify the cause of the nail changes.
questions.solution:

Leukonychia is the opaque whitish discolouration of the nail. It is seen in the following conditions:

  • Systemic diseases: Liver cirrhosis, renal failure, and cardiac failure
  • Miscellaneous: Trauma, malignancy, and toxins (arsenic, fluoride)
  • Idiopathic

Note: The leukonychia secondary to arsenic poisoning is termed - leukonychia striata or Aldrich–Mees lines.

questions.text:
Match the following:
1 - Kleptomania A - Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
2 - Pyromania B - Intense desire to mutilate
3 - Mutilomania C - Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
4 - Dipsomania D - Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the repeated failure to resist an impulse, drive, or urge to perform an act that is rewarding to the person, at least in the short-term, despite consequences such as long-term harm either to the individual or to others; marked distress about the behavior pattern; or significant impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

It includes

  1. Pyromania
  2. Kleptomania 
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are of no value to the person. The individual can usually afford the object or does not need it, but it is the act of stealing itself that is the goal. The stolen objects are usually given away, returned, or kept hidden. The act is not planned and is carried out alone.

Pyromania is the deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion. 

Pyromania is significantly associated with the following:

  • Substance abuse disorder (especially alcoholism).
  • Affective disorders (depression or bipolar)
  • Other impulse control disorders, such as kleptomania in female firesetters.
  • Personality disturbances, such as borderline personality disorders.
  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and learning disabilities in childhood pyromania.

Mutilomania is an irresistible impulse to mutilate animals.

Dipsomania is an irresistible impulse to drink alcohol at periodic intervals.

questions.text: A middle-aged farmer, presents to your OPD with complaints of decreased vision, redness, blurring of the eye, photophobia, and lacrimation. The patient reveals that a few days before the symptoms he had sustained an injury to the same eye with a vegetative matter. Slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding with anterior chamber involvement. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with the image depicting a corneal ulcer with arrowheads pointing towards satellite lesions and a thick hypopyon is suggestive of fungal keratitis.

Mycotic or fungal keratitis is seen in tropical countries and in immunocompromised individuals usually due to infection with Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida albicans. Injury by vegetative matter is a predisposing factor. Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but symptoms are usually milder in comparison to a bacterial ulcer.

Salient features that point toward the diagnosis of fungal corneal ulcers are:

  • Dry-looking ulcer with feathery margins.
  • Sterile circular corneal infiltrates - Wessley immune ring due to the deposition of immune complexes. 
  • Satellite lesions.
  • Thick, non-sterile hypopyon.

Topical drugs such as natamycin, voriconazole, amphotericin B, and nystatin can be used. Systemic antifungal agents such as ketoconazole are used if the ulcers are severe/perforated.

questions.text: The following fundus image shows ______.
questions.solution:
The image shows Drusens, which is a feature of dry or non-exudative age-related macular degeneration (AMD). 

Drusens are the earliest visible clinical signs of AMD. They are composed of lipid, amyloid, complement factors, and associated cellular components.

There are two types of ARMD.

  • Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) AMD is the most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed cases. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry AMD.
  • Wet (exudative, neovascular) AMD is much less common than the dry type, but it is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either prolonged latent phase. The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.

The first stage of labour consists of two phases :

  1. Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change (up to 5 cm of cervical dilatation).
  2. Active phase: This follows the latent phase and is characterized by regular painful uterine contractions, cervical effacement, and rapid cervical dilatation from 5 cm to full dilatation.

A latent phase that exceeds 20 hours in primigravidae or 14 hours in multiparae is termed as a prolonged latent phase of labour. Bed rest is the preferred treatment unless there is any indication for expediting the delivery.

The presence of false labour pains for a long time may be confused with a prolonged latent phase. The differences between them include

Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema No Yes

Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in a prolonged latent phase. There is no indication of the cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is present. Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phases due to the risk of infections.

  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)

  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.

  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: A 32 year old female nearing her due date has been admitted following regular contractions. The resident doctor did an examination and told the intern that the head is at +1 station. Where is the exact position of head?

choices.text: High up in the false pelvis

questions.solution:
The station is just below the ischial spine.

The station of the head is in relation to ischial spines as spines are the most prominent bony projections felt on internal examination.

The level of ischial spines is halfway between the pelvic inlet and outlet. This level is known as station zero (0).

The levels above and below the spines are divided into fifths to represent centimeters. The station is said to be “O” if the presenting part is at the level of the spines. The station is stated in minus figures if it is above the spines (–1 cm, –2 cm, –3 cm, –4 cm, and –5 cm) and in plus figures, if it is below the spines (+1 cm, +2 cm, +3 cm, +4 cm, and +5 cm).

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal. The clinical features of delirium tremens are:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension. And sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits, or malabsorption. It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by:

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C: Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D: Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

questions.text: The following type of nipple discharge is seen in?
questions.solution:
Green nipple discharge as seen in the above image can occur in duct ectasia.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is strongly associated with smoking. The initial stages of this disease consist of the dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with debris. Accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts acts as an irritant and leads to infection and inflammation. This causes periductal mastitis and subsequent fibrosis. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess. Opening of the abscess onto the skin leads to fistula formation. The persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation, which consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the finding given in the CT image?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the finding given in the CT image is pneumatised superior turbinate.

The superior turbinate is situated posterior and superior to the middle turbinate. It may get pneumatized by one or more cells. It forms an important landmark to identify the ostium of the sphenoid sinus which lies medial to it. Pneumatization is a commonly observed anatomical variation of the lateral nasal wall.

It can give rise to symptoms such as nasal obstruction, headache, epistaxis, anosmia, and postnasal drainage. In addition, it predisposes an individual to sinusitis by disrupting the mucociliary clearance and thereby affecting sinus drainage. It is usually an incidental finding on radiological examination and a CT scan helps in the diagnosis.

Superior turbinate pneumatization is mostly asymptomatic and does not require any treatment. However, when symptoms do occur, surgical techniques like outfracture, crushing, radio-frequency ablation, turbinoplasty, and microdebrider surgery may be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Pneumatization of middle turbinate leads to an enlarged middle turbinate which is ballooned out, this is called concha bullosa. 

The CT image shown below depicts concha bullosa.

Option C: Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal cell that may grow posteriorly, either by the side of the sphenoid sinus or superior to it. Onodi cell is surgically important as the optic nerve may be related to its lateral wall. 

A CT image of an onodi cell is shown below.

Option D: Haller cells are air cells situated in the roof of the maxillary sinus. They are pneumatized from anterior or posterior ethmoid cells. Enlargement of haller cells may lead to maxillary sinusitis as it may encroach the ethmoid infundibulum, impeding draining of the maxillary sinus.

A CT image of a haller cell is shown below.

Match the following syndromes with the vessels involved.
  1. Lateral medullary syndrome
  2. Medial medullary syndrome
  3. Weber's syndrome
  4. Lateral inferior pontine syndrome
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Circle of Willis and the marked vessels are:

  • A- Posterior cerebral artery
  • B- Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C- Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • D- Anterior spinal artery

The correct match is:

Syndromes Vessels involved
 Lateral medullary syndrome

Posterior inferior cerebellar artery.
Medial medullary syndrome Anterior spinal artery
Weber's syndrome Posterior cerebral artery
Lateral inferior pontine syndrome  Anterior inferior cerebellar artery

 

Circle of Willis is a large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

Lateral medullary syndrome/Wallenberg syndrome. This may result from a stroke affecting the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. 

The clinical findings correspond to the neuroanatomical structures affected in the lateral portion of the medulla:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal)- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia (gait and limb)
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • IX and X CN - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

Medial medullary syndrome. It is due to the involvement of the anterior spinal artery. Patients present with:

  • Lower motor neuron lesion of CN XII- Ipsilateral tongue weakness with deviation toward the lesion.
  • Medial lemniscus- Loss of contralateral touch and proprioception.
  • Pyramidal tract- Contralateral hemiparesis.

Weber syndrome: It is due to the involvement of the posterior cerebral artery. It affects the cranial nerve (CN) III, ventral midbrain, and corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiplegia and contralateral paralysis of the lower part of the face. Ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy where the eyeball is deviated laterally because of the paralysis of the medial rectus muscle, and drooping of the upper lid (ptosis). The pupil is dilated and fixed to light and accommodation.

The lateral inferior pontine syndrome is due to occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. Ipsilaterally it presents as,
  • Seventh nerve- Vertigo, horizontal and vertical nystagmus, and facial paralysis.
  • Cochlear nucleus- Paralysis of conjugate gaze to the affecting side (preservation of convergence), deafness, tinnitus.
  • Nucleus of trigeminal nerve- Impaired sensation over the face.

Contralaterally it presents as:

  • Spinothalamic tract- Impaired pain, and thermal sensation over one-half the body.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient presents to the OG OPD with complaints of menorrhagia. Sonogram revealed focal lesions within the endometrium.  The obstetrician performed the procedure given in the image below to assess the detailed anatomy of the endometrial cavity. Identify the investigation.
questions.solution:
The image depicts Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS), also known as sonohysterography.

Saline infusion sonography is a procedure where normal saline is injected into the uterine cavity and the uterus is imaged with transvaginal sonography. The SIS catheter was inserted transvaginally, blocking the infused sterile saline.

SIS displays the detailed endometrial cavity anatomy by distending the cavity with sterile saline (20 to 40 ml)

Usually done after a transvaginal sound detection of a mass / abnormal endometrial thickness. It also aids in infertility investigations and viewing endometrial thickness in select cases.

The image is given below.

Other options:

Option A: Transvaginal ultrasonography is a noninvasive imaging technique using the transvaginal approach. It provides a more detailed evaluation of the pelvic organs as compared to the transabdominal approach.

Option B: Harmonic imaging is an advanced ultrasound technique that enhances image resolution by using non-linear harmonic frequencies generated by tissue. It improves contrast, reduces artefacts, and provides clearer visualization of structures, especially in difficult-to-scan patients.

Option D: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging modality in which radiopaque contrast is injected through the cervical canal to assess the endometrial cavity, the fallopian tubes, and the endocervical canal. The image is given below.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele.

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

Other options:

Option A- Thyroglossal cyst is a midline cystic swelling usually affecting younger children. It can also occur at any age. It arises from the thyroglossal duct and can occur anywhere along the course of the thyroglossal duct. This swelling moves along with tongue protrusion as the thyroglossal duct is attached to the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue. It is managed by performing a Sistrunk operation.

The below image shows a patient with a thyroglossal cyst.

Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum in which the pharyngeal mucosa is herniated through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the 2 parts of the inferior constrictor). It usually occurs due to the uncoordinated contraction or the spasm of the cricopharyngeal sphincter during deglutition. Dysphagia is the predominant feature with a gurgling sound produced on swallowing. Regurgitation of undigested food and aspiration pneumonia are also seen. Barium swallow reveals the sac and its size.

The below image shows Zenker's diverticulum on barium swallow. 

Option D- Cystic hygroma occurs due to obstruction of the jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. More than 90% of the cases occur before the age of 2 years. It can result in stridor, respiratory difficulty, or feeding problems. It is partially compressible and brilliantly transilluminant.

The below image shows cystic hygroma in a child.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman has a long history of untreated papillary thyroid carcinoma. She complains of rapidly enlarging neck mass and difficulty eating. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly woman with rapidly enlarging neck mass and dysphagia in the setting of an untreated papillary carcinoma suggests a diagnosis of anaplastic thyroid cancer.

Anaplastic thyroid cancer is the most aggressive cancer and has the worst prognosis of all thyroid malignancies.

Almost all patients will be dead within 6 months. Radiotherapy and chemotherapy have not been shown to improve survival.

Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma:

  • It is a poorly-differentiated type of thyroid carcinoma
  • Typical manifestation is an elderly female with rapidly enlarging neck mass, dysphagia, and cervical tenderness.
  • Patients usually have a history of untreated differentiated thyroid carcinoma (DTC).
  • Local invasion to recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) causes hoarseness. It may also cause tracheal obstruction.
  • Distant metastasis is more common in lungs via hematogenous route.
  • Diagnosis is made by FNAC. However, tru-cut/open biopsy is frequently used to confirm the diagnosis in cases of doubt.
  • Management:
    • If metastasis is absent: Total thyroidectomy + LN dissection
    • If metastasis is present: Palliative care with chemotherapy and radiotherapy
    • In cases of tracheal obstruction: Isthmectomy to relieve obstruction

Other options:

Option A: Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is a rare thyroid malignancy arising from parafollicular C cells, which produce calcitonin. It can occur sporadically or as part of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes.

Option B: Hürthle cell carcinoma (HCC) is a rare and aggressive thyroid cancer arising from Hürthle cells, a variant of follicular thyroid cells. It is known for its resistance to radioactive iodine therapy and potential for distant metastasis.

Option C: Papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy, arising from follicular cells and often linked to radiation exposure. It typically has a good prognosis with slow growth and a high cure rate.

questions.text: Thirty minutes after a blood transfusion is started, the patient develops chills and severe flank pain. Temperature is 102.4 F and she begins bleeding around her IV catheter site. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR).

This patient presents with high-grade fever (102.4 F and chills), flank pain and features suggestive of DIC (bleeding around her IV catheter site), 30 minutes after transfusion was started. The time course and presentation is consistent with acute hemolytic reaction.

Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR)

  • occurs within 24 hour of transfusion
  • fever, flank pain, hemoglobinuria, renal failure, and DIC
  • Caused by ABO incompatibility, Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction
  • Positive Direct Coomb's test, pink plasma
  • Transfusion to be stopped immediately.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for a leg ulcer. What is the mechanism by which a graft receives its nutritional supply on postoperative day 3?
questions.solution:
The phase of skin graft uptake in which the graft receives its nutritional supply on postoperative day 3 is known as inosculation. It is the period during which the graft is most at risk for failure. 

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hours because of the imbibition (option B) of plasma from the wound bed.
  • After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to the inosculation of blood.
  • Neovascularization (option D ) is the process by which new blood vessels form, directly invading the graft and restoring the pink color of the skin. There is no step of diffusion (option C) in the process of graft transplantation.

Skin grafts can be broadly divided into two categories:

Split-thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. More dermis in the full-thickness skin graft translates into more primary contraction and less secondary contraction.

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such
  • as burns.
  • Uptake is good.
  • Meshing can be done, i.e., small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this, improving graft takeup. It also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post-graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

questions.text: What is the condition seen in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows conjoined twins with fusion in the pelvic region, which is known as ischiopagus.

In monochorionic monoamniotic twinning, incomplete duplication of the embryonic disc can occur. Incomplete separation of the monozygotic twins results in the birth of two infants that are joined or fused together at some part of the body. These twins are known as conjoined twins or Siamese twins.

Depending on the degree of incomplete separation, different types of conjoined twins can form:

  • Thoracopagus: United at the thorax

  • Omphalopagous or Xiphipagous: United anteriorly from the xiphoid to the umbilicus
  • Parapagus: Lateral fusion with two heads, sharing a single thorax, abdomen, and pelvis (most common)
  • Ischiopagus: United at the pelvis 
  • Pygopagus: United in the sacral region
  • Heteropagous: Asymmetric forms

questions.solution:
The image shows Warren's shunt (distal lienorenal shunt). This is the only selective shunt out of the four options given hence it has the least risk of hepatic encephalopathy. 

TIPS(Transjugular Intravenous Porto Systemic shunt):

The main indication of TIPS is variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. A guidewire is inserted via the internal jugular vein and superior vena cava into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The major complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure >5 mmHg.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a treatment option whereby a percutaneous connection is created within the liver, between the portal and systemic circulations, to reduce portal pressure in patients with complications related to portal hypertension.

  • Early complication- hepatic encephalopathy
  • Late complication- recurrent variceal bleed
  • Delayed complication- total shunt occlusion

questions.text: Which among the following is the cause of the ECG finding shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given ECG finding is known as torsades de pointes, which can occur due to hypomagnesemia.

Torsades de pointes means twisting of points, it implies twisting of the QRS complexes around the isoelectric line of the ECG. It is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that is seen in patients with a prolonged QT interval. 

There is QT interval prolongation in the ECG due to a non-uniform delay in repolarization.
