questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing a direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  Which of the following is true with respect to the stridor seen in this baby?

choices.text: Increases in prone position and subsides on crying
Subsides on prone position and increases with crying
Subsides both on crying and prone position
Increases with both prone position and crying

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of laryngomalacia, as the image shows the omega-shaped epiglottis and the stridor associated with this condition subsides on placing the child in a prone position but increases with crying.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Treatment of laryngomalacia is mainly conservative, as it self-corrects by the time the child is 2 years of age. Tracheostomy may be required in some cases with severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: A patient with thyrotoxicosis is being prepared for surgery. Which of the following statements regarding the pre-operative preparation of this patient is wrong?

choices.text: Iodine may be given pre-operatively with Carbimazole
Beta blockers administered pre-operatively must be continued post operatively
Nadolol is given in a once daily regimen pre-operatively
The last dose of Carbimazole must be given 24 hours before surgery

questions.solution:
The last dose of carbimazole may be given the evening before surgery. Beta-blockers, however, if used preoperatively must be given on the morning of surgery as well, and be continued for 1-week post-op. 

Traditional preparation of a thyrotoxic patient aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid. There are 2 methods of preparation that can be used. 

  • Carbimazole 30-40 mg per day is the drug of choice. When euthyroid (after 8-12 weeks), the dose may be reduced or a block and replace regimen may be used. In the latter case, the patient is supplemented with 0.1-0.15 mg of Thyroxine. 
  • An alternative method is to abolish the clinical manifestations using beta-blockade, which acts on the target organs and not the gland itself. The appropriate doses are Propranolol 40 mg TDS or a longer-acting nadolol 160 mg once daily. It is important to continue treatment upto 7 days post-operatively as beta-blockers do not interfere with the synthesis of hormones and hormone levels may remain high for some days post Thyroidectomy. 

Iodine may be given with Carbimazole or a beta-blocker 10 days before the operation. Iodine produces transient remission if given alone and reduces vascularity, increasing the margin of safety. However, its use is not universal as there are more effective regimens. If Beta-blockers are mistakenly omitted on the morning of surgery, Iodides serve as an extra measure of safety.

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of recurrent pain and discharge due to lesions around the anus, shown in the image is likely to be a fistula-in-ano.

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal connection between the anal canal and the perianal skin, lined with granulation tissue. It may follow the drainage of a perianal abscess or may be seen in association with diseases like tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Clinical features are perianal pain, swelling, and intermittent purulent discharge, which might be blood-stained. On examination, one or more external openings may be visible.

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula. Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract. Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

 

 

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano can include a fistulogram, endoanal ultrasound with hydrogen peroxide, MRI, and computed tomography (CT) scan. An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. 

Surgical management includes fistulotomy, fistulectomy, ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT), setons, or advancement flaps.

Other options:

Option A: Pilonidal sinus is a chronic skin condition in the sacrococcygeal region caused by hair penetration leading to infection and abscess formation. It commonly affects young adults and may require surgical drainage or excision for treatment.

Option B: A carbuncle is a deep, painful skin infection involving a cluster of interconnected boils (furuncles), usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It commonly occurs on the back, neck, or thighs and may require drainage and antibiotics for treatment.

Option C: A boil, or furuncle, is a painful, pus-filled infection of a hair follicle caused by bacteria, usually Staphylococcus aureus. It typically presents as a red, swollen lump and may require drainage if severe.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with hematuria and a neovascular mass in the left kidney on a CT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CT image showing renal lesions that has hypo-attenuating components consistent with macroscopic fat is highly suggestive of renal angiomyolipoma.

Angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. The mean age of presentation is 43 years and there is a female predilection. It can present as spontaneous retroperitoneal hemorrhage, especially with larger tumors. The patient can present with flank pain, palpable mass, hematuria, urinary tract infections, hypertension, or renal failure. 

Imaging in renal angiomyolipoma: Demonstration of macroscopic fat is the main part of making a diagnosis. USG may show hyperechoic lesions in the cortex with posterior acoustic shadowing. In patients with tuberous sclerosis, the entire kidney is affected and produces an echogenic appearance with loss of normal corticomedullary junction.

CT findings:

  • Cortical lesions that demonstrate macroscopic fat (less than -20 HU)
  • Absence of ossification or calcification
  • The presence of macroscopic fat is strongly suggestive of this condition, but not pathognomonic as RCC may rarely demonstrate macroscopic fat.
  • Approximately 5% may be fat-poor.

MRI: It is an excellent tool to demonstrate intramural fat components. Two sequences are used:

  • Fat-saturated techniques 
  • Phase-in and phase-out imaging that shows India ink artifacts at the junction between fat and non-fat components.

Digital subtraction angiography: They are hypervascular lesions showing a 'sunburst appearance' in the arterial phase and an 'onion peel appearance' in the venous phase.

They usually do not require any intervention. mTOR inhibitors like everolimus can be used to decrease the size of the lesion.

Other options:

Option A: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC): It is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50-70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It is a differential for angiomyolipoma but it is important to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

Option B: Renal oncocytoma: They are relatively benign in nature and usually present in the 6th to 7th decade. An important point regarding this tumor is its similarity with RCC and hence it is very difficult to differentiate between them preoperatively. A sharp central stellate scar may be seen in one-third of the cases. But RCC may also show this stellate scar appearance in some cases.

Option D: Renal cyst: It is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions needs evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification of renal cysts is given above.

questions.text: What is the most common mode of spread in ovarian malignancies ?
questions.solution:
The transcoelomic route is the most common and the earliest mode of spread in ovarian malignancies.

By this route, tumor cells spilled into the peritoneal cavity follow the path of the peritoneal fluid during respiration and get deposited in areas such as the paracolic gutter, cul-de-sac (pouch of Douglas), hemidiaphragm, mesenteries of the intestine, and the liver capsule.

Lymphatics is the next common mode of spread, especially in the advanced stages of the disease. The common sites involved are the para-aortic and pelvic nodes.

Hematogenous spread is uncommon and can seed a nidus in the parenchyma of organs such as the lung and the liver.Right pleural effusion is a common finding. This mode of spread mostly occur in survivors of the malignancy.

Transcoelomic spread > lymphatic spread > hematogenous spread

questions.text:
Which of the following are extra-esophageal complications associated with GERD?
  1. Asthma
  2. Laryngitis
  3. Pulmonary fibrosis
  4. Cough
questions.solution:
Asthma,laryngitis,pulmonary fibrosis and cough are extra esophageal complications in gastroesophageal reflux disease(GERD)
 
 Extraoesophageal symptoms of GERD are:

  • Chronic cough
  • Laryngitis,
  • Asthma
  • Dental erosions (especially on the lingual and palatal tooth
    surfaces).
  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Sinusitis
  • Pharyngitis
  • Recurrent otitis media

Extraesophageal symptoms of GERD originate from the respiratory tract and include both laryngeal and pulmonary issues These symptoms can arise through two mechanisms. The first and most common mechanism involves proximal esophageal reflux and microaspiration of gastroduodenal contents, which cause direct injury to the larynx and lower respiratory tract. The second mechanism involves distal esophageal acid exposure triggering a vagal nerve reflex, leading to bronchospasm and cough, due to the shared vagal innervation of the trachea and esophagus.

The incidence of Barrett's esophagus is also more in patients with long term GERD, which in turn increases the risk of adenocarcinoma of esophagus.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with a history of headache since a few weeks and an inability to visualise his lateral fields. Examination shows the following findings. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

Hemianopia or hemianopsia refers to loss of sight in half the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours. Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, and suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia to emphasize the fact that the parts of the visual field that are lost in each eye do not overlap.

Individuals with this condition are able to see in both left and right central visual fields, with both eyes open. However, all information from the most peripheral parts of visual fields (which are seen only by the nasal retinas) is lost.

Other options: 

Lesions at the occipital lobe, optic tract and optic radiation would all cause homonymous hemianopia. Here, either the right or left half of the binocular field of vision is lost, due to the loss of the temporal half of one field and the nasal half of the other.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is anterior uveitis. The image shows keratic precipitates in the cornea and festooned pupil which are characteristic of anterior uveitis.

Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the anterior portion of the uveal tract consisting of the iris and anterior ciliary body.

Anterior uveitis is characterized by: 

  • Koeppe nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at the pupillary margin
  • Busacca nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at collarette 
  • Keratic precipitates (KP) - proteinaceous deposits on the corneal endothelium. These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. Types of KP's include - 
    • Mutton fat type - seen in granulomatous uveitis
    • Granular type - seen in non-granulomatous uveitis
  • Aqueous flare - diffuse inflammation with exudates in the anterior chamber. It is the earliest sign of non-granulomatous uveitis

The exudates can also pour out into the posterior chamber causing the iris to adhere posteriorly to the lens. When the adhesions organize to become fibrous, it becomes firm and is known as posterior synechiae. 

A festooned pupil is an irregularly shaped pupil that is seen when segmental posterior synechiae are formed. When mydiatrics are administered in this condition, there is dilatation of the pupillary portions that have not yet adhered to the lens, leading to festooned pupil.

 

Other options:

Options A and C: Acute congestive glaucoma and acute conjunctivitis are both differential diagnoses for acute anterior uveitis. However, they do not have the characteristic feature of keratic precipitates.

Option D: Keratoconus or conical cornea is a non-inflammatory condition of the axial cornea. Central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea are pathognomonic.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the middle finger around the proximal phalanx. An X-ray was done and it is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette and X-ray findings point toward the diagnosis of enchondroma.

Enchondromas are benign tumors consisting of a lobulated mass of cartilage encapsulated by fibrous tissue. It is more commonly seen in 20 to 30 years of age. Small bones of hands and feet are commonly involved followed by the femur and humerus. 

The patient usually presents with long-standing swelling from one or more phalanges or metacarpals, without much pain. Diagnosis can be done by X-ray, which can show expanding lytic lesions, occasionally, a biopsy will be required if the diagnosis is unclear. Enchondromas of long bones may undergo malignant transformation into chondrosarcoma.

Treatment is removal by curettage and it is indicated if there is pain or pathological fracture.

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone that produces osteoid matrix or mineralized bone.  X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance as shown below.

Option B: Ewing's sarcoma is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after osteosarcoma. Onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is seen on radiology (as shown below) and Homer-Wright rosettes, which are round groupings of cells with a central fibrillary core may be seen histologically.

Option C: Osteoclastoma is also called a giant cell tumour because multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells are present on histology. The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumor showing an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and the typical soap bubble appearance

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a past history of tuberculosis presents to the OPD  with complaints of chronic cough, occasional hemoptysis, and persistent chest pain. Chest X-ray shows the following lesion. It has been observed that when the patient's position changes, the air within the lesion changes as well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a past history of tuberculosis with an X-ray showing Monod's sign is suggestive of aspergilloma. The gas/air surrounding a mobile fungal ball or mycetoma (usually an aspergilloma) in an already-existing lung cavity is referred to as the Monod sign.

Aspergilloma or fungal ball is a late manifestation of chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) caused by Aspergillus species. A fungal ball is formed within the pulmonary cavity of CPA by the peeled-off inner layer of the cavity. 

Patients present with chronic features of fatigue, weight loss, cough, hemoptysis, and wheezing. However, clinical features such as foul-smelling sputum and night sweats are more commonly observed in Tuberculosis which helps in differentiating the two conditions.

Chest X-ray shows a spherical or ovoid mass within a cavity. The mass is mobile. CT demonstrates a rounded mass within a cavity.

Images below show chest x-ray and CT findings in aspergilloma.

Other options:

Option A: Lung abscess typically shows a thick-walled cavity with air-fluid level as shown below.

Option B & D: Hydatid cyst and bronchogenic carcinoma can also show cavitatory lesions with air crescent but a preformed cavity from the past history of tuberculosis suggests the diagnosis of aspergilloma.

You are a medical officer on camp duty seeing patients who have come for the removal of contraceptive devices. You notice the following contraceptive devices being used. Which of the following is incorrect about these devices?

Pelvic Inflammatory Disease - PID

questions.solution:
The image shows types of Copper T. The statement that it 'can be used in patients with menorrhagia' is incorrect about the copper T. Copper T's are contraindicated in patients with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and anemia as it can worsen the condition. 

Copper T is a type of intrauterine contraception device (IUCD). They provide long-term, reversible method of contraception.

Types:

  • Medicated IUCD's such as progestasert, levonova, and mirena which release hormones for contraception.
  • Unmedicated IUCD's such as the copper T, in order to induce contraception. 

The copper T functions by causing an inflammatory response (Option D) within the uterus which leads to spermicide. The same response also makes it difficult for blastocyst implantation. 

IUCDs can be placed in women who have a low risk of sexually transmitted diseases, are multiparous, monogamous, and want long-term contraception without permanent sterilization. These have the advantage of not having to take a daily oral contraceptive pill. 

The copper T can also be used as emergency contraception (Option A) and left inside the uterus long term for contraception. 

It is contraindicated in the following situations: 

  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Fibroid uterus (Option C) as there will be structural issues
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease or lower genital tract infections
  • Menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea
  • Anemia
  • Uncontrolled diabetes due to increased risk of infection
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy 
  • Scarred uterus
  • Abnormally shaped uterus

In addition, hormonal IUCDs should not be given in women with history of breast cancer. 

The following image shows the Nova T. It has silver in addition to the copper wire which makes its lifespan 5 years. 

The copper T 380A is also known as Paraguard. It has a lifespan of 10 years. It has 380 mm2 surface area spread out across the stem and the sleeves. 

The multiload 375 has 375 mm2 of copper wire wrapped around the stem. It has to be replaced every 5 years. It does not have an introducer or plunger. 

The copper T 200 has 215mm2 of copper around the stem. It has a polyethylene frame with monofilaments attached to the end of the stem. The threads are used for removal. Barium sulfate is added to the stem to increase radioopacity when performing xrays. It has a lifespan of 3 years.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, who is a chronic alcoholic, presented to the casualty following 2 episodes of haematemesis and is currently hypotensive. The surgery resident on duty tries to control the bleeding with the instrument shown below. Identify this instrument.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding. Temporary hemostasis can be achieved with the help of balloon tamponades. The above image shows the Sengstaken-Blakemore tube.

It has 1 suction tube and 2 inflation tubes. The 3 openings are:

  • Gastric balloon port
  • Esophageal balloon port
  • Gastric aspiration port

The gastric balloon is inflated and tension is applied to the gastroesophageal junction. If this does not control the haemorrhage, the esophageal balloon is inflated as well, compressing the venous plexus between them. Only gastric contents can be aspirated.

  • Two suction tubes:
    • Gastric aspiration port
    • Esophageal aspiration port
  • Two inflation tubes:
    • Gastric balloon port
    • Oesophageal balloon port

This tube allows the aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

The image below depicts the Minnesota tube. 

Option C: Linton-Nachlas tube has only two ports and a single gastric balloon. 

Option D: Ewald's tube is generally used for gastric lavage. It has only one aspiration port for the stomach.

questions.text: The spinal x-ray of a patient with elevated ALP levels is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above x-ray shows a rugger jersey spine which is a distinct feature of hyperparathyroidism. It is associated with elevated ALP.

It refers to the prominent hyperdensities at the endplates of successive vertebrae, which mimics the striped appearance of a rugby jersey. 

Other radiographic changes in hyperparathyroidism are:

  • Subperiosteal bone resorption - radial aspects of proximal and middle phalanges of the second and third fingers
  • Terminal tuft erosion of phalanges or acro-osteolysis
  • Osteopenia
  • Brown tumors or osteitis fibrosa cystica
  • Salt and pepper appearance of skull or pepperpot skull

Option A: Paget's disease causes cortical thickening, which results in increased opacity on all sides of the vertebral body. These are called picture frame vertebrae.

Option C: Osteopetrosis presents with normal ALP levels. It results in sclerotic endplates of vertebrae that are termed sandwich vertebrae. Though this finding is similar to the rugger jersey spine, it is denser and more sharply defined than the rugger jersey spine. In addition, there is sclerosis of inner margins of vertebral bodies, resulting in a bone within a bone appearance.

 

Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis produces a bamboo spine appearance due to the fusion of vertebral bodies.

questions.text: A patient with a known history of ulcerative colitis presents with abdominal pain, distention, and fever for the past 3 days. Her abdomen is distended, tympanic and tender to palpation. Plain abdominal X-ray is shown below. She has leukocytosis and elevated ESR and CRP. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient with a past history of inflammatory bowel disease with abdominal pain and distension with fever coupled with colonic dilation on X-Ray makes toxic megacolon the likely diagnosis. The most appropriate management in this patient is the administration of high-dose intravenous corticosteroids.

The goal is to curb colonic inflammation, reducing the risk of perforation. Typically, these high-dose corticosteroids are given over 3-5 days. If there is an inadequate clinical or radiological response, colectomy becomes the subsequent step in management.

Toxic megacolon is a life-threatening complication of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), most commonly ulcerative colitis, characterized by rapid colonic dilation, ileus, and systemic toxicity. Prompt diagnosis and intervention are crucial due to the high risk of perforation and mortality.

Abdominal radiography shows transverse or right colonic dilation of >6 cm and loss of haustrations. It usually resolves with supportive treatment (correcting electrolyte imbalance, fluids, bowel rest) and medical therapy which includes glucocorticoids, anti-inflammatory drugs, and antibiotics. However, an urgent colectomy is indicated in patients who do not show signs of improvement.

Other options:

Option B: Total abdominal colectomy with ileostomy, is a definitive surgical intervention but is usually reserved for patients with refractory toxic megacolon or those with contraindications to corticosteroids.

Option C: Advising the patient to be nil per oral with observation is insufficient management for toxic megacolon as it is a life-threatening condition.

Option  D: Oral mesalamine and antibiotics are not effective in treating toxic megacolon due to the severity of the inflammation and the need for systemic therapy. Antibiotics may be used empirically to cover potential bacterial translocation but are not the primary treatment.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with a history of moderate persistent asthma on treatment presents with progressive worsening of shortness of breath, wheezing, and cough over 3 days. Her husband gave a history suggestive of a recent upper respiratory tract infection. Now she is unable to speak in complete sentences. On examination, there is an increased respiratory rate, tachycardia, and cyanosis. ABG shows hypoxemia and low PaCO2. The X-ray taken is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute severe asthma.

Acute severe asthma is usually triggered by viral upper respiratory infection, exposure to allergens, cold or exercise. The patient presents with progressive chest tightness and loud wheezing not relieved by inhaler. They may be agitated and have difficulty in speaking.

On examination, there will be:

  • Increased respiratory rate, tachycardia and cyanosis
  • low PaCO2 (i.e. Respiratory alkalosis) due to hyperventilation
  • Pulsus paradoxus may be seen
  • Chest X-ray is usually normal but can show hyperinflated lungs. (as shown in the image above)

On the contrary, Asthma with impending respiratory failure will have a normal or rising PaCO2, in a mute/silent patient with relative bradycardia, a silent chest(absent wheeze) and respiratory acidosis.

Other options:

Option A: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a life-threatening condition characterized by severe hypoxemia, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, and decreased lung compliance due to non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema. It is commonly triggered by sepsis, pneumonia, trauma, or aspiration.

Option B: Asthma with impending respiratory failure is characterized by severe dyspnea, a silent chest, altered mental status, and rising CO₂ levels (hypercapnia) due to respiratory muscle fatigue. Immediate intervention with oxygen, bronchodilators, corticosteroids, and possible ventilatory support is crucial.

Option C: Acute pneumothorax is the sudden accumulation of air in the pleural space, causing lung collapse, sharp chest pain, and dyspnea. It can be spontaneous or traumatic and may require needle decompression or chest tube placement if severe.

questions.text:
Which of the following can be classified as ionizing radiation?
  1. Alpha rays
  2. Beta rays
  3. Gamma rays
  4. X-rays
  5. MRI
questions.solution:
Among the given options, alpha rays, beta rays, gamma rays, and x-rays are ionizing radiations. MRI is an example of non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. 

Ionizing radiation is a type of radiation with enough energy to remove tightly bound electrons from the orbit of an atom, causing the atom to be charged or ionized. They can be either directly ionizing or indirectly ionizing. Alpha rays and beta rays are directly ionizing radiation because they carry a charge and can directly interact with atomic electrons. Alpha and beta rays are also particulate radiation (composed of particles). 

Gamma rays and x-rays are electromagnetic rays. They are indirectly ionizing radiation as they are electrically neutral and do not interact directly with electrons. 

MRI is a technique that produces topographic images by means of magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves. It uses non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. MRI is based on the ability of nuclei of certain atoms to absorb and emit radio wave energy when the body is placed within a strong magnetic field.

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient who had the surgery 3 months back presents with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. On fundoscopy, there is a honeycomb appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and a honeycomb appearance on fundoscopy is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows loss of foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  honeycomb appearance. In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:

Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B- Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option C- Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:

Option D- Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It is indicated when the patient is symptomatic.

questions.text: Cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in _________
questions.solution:
Cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in Central cord syndrome.

It results from selective damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the decussating spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. These decussating fibers carry crude touch, pain, and temperature sensations.

Spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors are the main causes.

Central cord syndrome affects the cervical cord producing arm weakness out of proportion to leg weakness. A “dissociated” sensory loss i.e. loss of pain and temperature with preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sensations is seen over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution).

questions.text: A patient, who is on treatment for hypertension came to the OPD for follow up. Which of the following drugs must be preferably avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors are preferably avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis.

Bilateral renal artery stenosis (BRAS) is the narrowing of both renal arteries, leading to reduced kidney perfusion and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), causing hypertension and potential renal dysfunction.

In patients with BRAS, ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) and ARBs (e.g., losartan) should generally be avoided as they can reduce glomerular filtration pressure by dilating the efferent arteriole, potentially leading to acute kidney injury (AKI). Additionally, direct renin inhibitors (e.g., aliskiren) and potassium-sparing diuretics should be used cautiously due to the risk of worsening renal function and hyperkalemia.

Other options:

Option B, C and D: Diuretics, beta blockers and calcium channel blockers are antihypertensive drugs that can be used in bilateral renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the clinic after he experienced palpitations. He has a history of ischemic heart disease (IHD).  Which of the following drugs can be used to treat the condition identified on the given ECG:
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows a narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels, leading to slower repolarization and causing an increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

Other options:

Option B: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension, angina, and arrhythmias. It works by inhibiting calcium influx into cardiac and vascular smooth muscle, reducing heart rate and blood pressure.

Option C: Flecainide is a class Ic antiarrhythmic drug used to treat supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias. It works by blocking sodium channels, stabilizing cardiac electrical activity, and preventing abnormal heart rhythms.

Option D: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and atrial fibrillation by increasing myocardial contractility and reducing heart rate. It works by inhibiting the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, increasing intracellular calcium.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent episodes of fever with chills. MRCP image of the patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?

MRCP- Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The above MRCP shows multiple areas of intrahepatic narrowing with alternating areas of normal and dilated segments of bile ducts typical for primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis is characterized by inflammatory strictures involving intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree. It eventually leads to secondary biliary cirrhosis. It is associated with ulcerative colitis and also with Riedel’s thyroiditis and retroperitoneal fibrosis. 10–20% of patients develop cholangiocarcinoma

It affects the age group 30–45 years with male: female ratio of 2:1. The clinical features include intermittent jaundice, fatigue, weight loss, pruritus, and abdominal pain. The bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels are raised.

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiography (ERC) is a gold standard in diagnosis and shows multiple dilatations and strictures (beading) of both intra and extrahepatic biliary tree.

Currently, there is no known effective medical therapy. Surgical management with resection of extrahepatic biliary tree and hepaticojejunostomy has shown reasonable effects. For patients with sclerosing cholangitis with advanced liver disease, liver transplantation is the only available option.

Other options:

Option B: Caroli disease is a rare congenital disorder characterized by segmental dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. It can lead to recurrent cholangitis, bile duct stones, and an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

Option C: Oriental cholangitis, also known as recurrent pyogenic cholangitis, is a chronic biliary disease prevalent in Southeast Asia. It is characterized by intrahepatic pigment stones, biliary obstruction, and recurrent infections.

Option D: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is a chronic autoimmune liver disease that leads to progressive destruction of small intrahepatic bile ducts. It can cause cholestasis, liver fibrosis, and eventually cirrhosis if untreated.

questions.text: A patient suspected of tubal pregnancy undergoes a transvaginal ultrasound, which is inconclusive. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Serum Beta hCG levels are the investigation to be performed if TVS is inconclusive. It confirms that a pregnancy is present.

Tubal pregnancy, a type of ectopic pregnancy, occurs when a fertilized egg implants in the fallopian tube instead of the uterus. It is a life-threatening condition that can lead to tubal rupture and severe internal bleeding if untreated. Beta-hCG levels play a crucial role in diagnosis, as they typically rise more slowly than in a normal intrauterine pregnancy.

In a normal pregnancy, beta-hCG levels double every 48 hours, whereas in an ectopic pregnancy, they often rise abnormally or plateau. A beta-hCG level of ≥1500–2000 mIU/mL without an intrauterine gestational sac on ultrasound strongly suggests ectopic pregnancy.

Serial beta-hCG monitoring helps guide management, which may include medical treatment with methotrexate or surgical intervention if rupture occurs. Symptoms include pelvic pain, vaginal bleeding, and dizziness, especially if rupture leads to hemorrhagic shock. Early detection and prompt treatment are essential to prevent complications and preserve fertility.

Levels, if greater than 1500 IU/L, tell us that there is some problem with the pregnancy such as:

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Dead fetus
  • Miscarriage

Note: Serum beta HCG can detect a pregnancy as early as 5 days before the first missed period.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium?
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of vaginal discharge during puerperium- Lochia rubra>Lochia serosa>Lochia alba.

Lochia is the vaginal discharge for the first fortnight during puerperium that originates from the uterine body, cervix, and vagina.

Depending upon the variation of the color of the discharge, it is named:

(1) Lochia rubra- Seen in 1–4 days after delivery. The color of the discharge is red. It consists of blood, shreds of fetal membranes and decidua, vernix caseosa, lanugo, and meconium.

(2) Lochia serosa- Seen during 5-9 days. The color is yellowish or pink or pale brownish. It consists mainly of leukocytes, wound exudate, mucus from the cervix, and micro-organisms (anaerobic streptococci and staphylococci). The presence of bacteria is not pathognomonic unless associated with clinical signs of sepsis.

(3) Lochia alba- Seen during 10–15 days. The color of the discharge is pale white. Lochia alba contains plenty of decidual cells, leukocytes, mucus, cholesterin crystals, fatty and granular epithelial cells, and microorganisms.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with involuntary weight loss of >10% associated with chronic diarrhea for > 30 days. He was diagnosed with wasting syndrome. Which of the following is least likely to be responsible for weight loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Wasting syndrome/ generalized wasting is an AIDS-defining condition associated with involuntary weight loss of >10% of body weight, fever and chronic diarrhoea lasting >30 days without any other cause. Lipoatrophy is not responsible for weight loss in this condition.

The majority of the weight loss in this condition is due to a loss of muscle mass, also known as lean body mass or body cell mass. Bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) or a full body x-ray (DEXA) scan is used to measure it.

A constant feature of this syndrome is severe muscle wasting with scattered myofiber degeneration and occasional evidence of myositis.

Glucocorticoids may be of some benefit. Androgenic steroids, growth hormone, and total parenteral nutrition have all been used as therapeutic interventions, with varying degrees of success.

Wasting syndrome is rarely seen nowadays due to the early initiation of antiretroviral drugs.

HIV-associated lipodystrophy is a side effect of antiretroviral therapy (ART) that occurs due to the redistribution of adipose tissue. It can manifest as fat accumulation (lipohypertrophy) or fat loss (lipoatrophy).

Lipoatrophy is characterised by subcutaneous fat loss in the face, arms, legs, abdomen, and/or buttocks. There is preferential fat loss with no evidence of muscle atrophy, which distinguishes it from AIDS-related wasting syndrome.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

1) Salt and pepper appearance A) Hurler's syndrome
2) J-shaped sella B) Paget's disease
3) Punched-out lesions C) Hyperparathyroidism
4) Cotton wool appearance D) Multiple myeloma
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

  • Salt and pepper appearance - Hyperparathyroidism 
  • J-shaped sella - Hurler's syndrome
  • Punched-out lesions - Multiple myeloma
  • Cotton wool appearance - Paget's disease

Salt and pepper appearance of the skull: It is also known as pepper pot skull and is seen in hyperparathyroidism. It is characterized by multiple tiny well-defined lucencies in the skull that occur due to resorption of the trabecular bone.

Other radiological findings in hyperparathyroidism:

  • Sub-periosteal resorption - Classical and pathognomonic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Loss of lamina dura 
  • Expansile lytic lesion, otherwise known as brown tumor, generally affecting maxilla/ mandible

Image showing salt and pepper appearance of the skull:

\J-shaped sella - It is a skull radiographic finding in Hurler's syndrome.

Other radiological findings in Hurler's syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

Note:

J-shaped sella can also be seen in other conditions like optic chiasm glioma, hydrocephalus, neurofibromatosis, as a normal anatomic variant, etc.

Punched-out lesions - It is frequently associated with multiple myeloma. 

Other important causes for punched-out skull lesions include metastatic lesions, tuberculosis, sarcoidosis, epidermoid tumor, fibrous dysplasia, etc.

Cotton wool appearance - It is seen in Paget's disease of the bone. It refers to the mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull.

Other skull radiological findings in Paget's disease:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta - Large well-defined lytic lesions involving the inner part of the outer table of the skull with an intact inner table
  • Diploic widening
  • Tam o' Shanter sign

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent episodes of rhinitis. He is a gold smith and works in hot, dry and dusty surroundings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Rhinitis sicca is seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings.
Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in people who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers and iron- and goldsmiths. It usually affects the anterior third of the nose, particularly the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia, along with atrophy of the seromucinous glands. The affected areas develop crusts, which may result in bleeding, ulceration, and even septal perforation on removal.

Treatment consists of correction of the occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment to the affected part. Ointments with antibiotics and steroids can also be used.

Other options:

Option A: Rhinitis caseosa is a condition in which the nose is filled with purulent discharge/cheesy material. It is a unilateral condition mostly affecting males. This condition usually results from chronic sinusitis, where the mucosa of the sinuses becomes granulomatous and the sinuses are filled with cheesy material. Management includes the removal of debris and ensuring good drainage of the sinuses.

Option C: Secondary atrophic rhinitis is a condition when atrophic changes in the nasal cavity occur secondary to specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy, and rhinoscleroma.

Option D: Hypertrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum, and bone. It occurs as a result of recurrent nasal infections, chronic sinusitis, and chronic irritation of the nasal mucosa. Symptoms include nasal obstruction, discharge, and headache.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the paediatrician with complaints of bilateral knee pain. His bone mineral density is normal.  The X-ray image of the joints is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the X-ray showing Pelkan spurs, Trummerfeld zone, and Frenkel's line are suggestive of scurvy.

Radiological findings in scurvy:

  • Frenkel's line - Zone of provisional calcification at the growing metaphysis is seen as a dense, white line called the Frankel's line.
  • Pelkan spurs - These are metaphyseal spurs formed due to fractures manifesting at the cortical margins. 
  • Wimberger’s ring sign - The sclerotic rim around the epiphysis forms this appearance.
  • Trummerfeld zone. - Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line.

Scurvy results from the deficiency of vitamin C, which is required for the hydroxylation of lysine and proline in procollagen. There is the defective formation of connective tissue and collagen in the skin, bone, cartilage, dentine, and blood vessels which leads to their fragility.

Early manifestations include irritability, loss of appetite, musculoskeletal pain, and tenderness in the legs. Later on, the child can have swelling of the knees, ankles, and pseudo paralysis. Hemorrhagic manifestations of scurvy include petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, and characteristic perifollicular haemorrhages.

Other manifestations are poor wound and fracture healing, hyperkeratosis of hair follicles, arthralgia, and muscle weakness. It also results in defective osteoid formation. Costo-chondral separation leads to the formation of tender nodules, which are sharply angulated also known as the scorbutic rosary.

Other options:

Option C: Metaphyseal dysplasia: It is also known as Pyle's disease. There is a failure of remodelling the metaphysis. Erlenmeyer flask deformities of the distal femur and proximal tibia are seen in this condition. The patient can also develop genu valgum.

Option D: Pycnodysostosis: It is an autosomal recessive condition due to a mutation in the cathepsin K (CTSK) gene. It causes osteosclerosis and the affected individual has distinctive facial features and skeletal malformations. The patient has short stature and is prone to recurrent fractures due to their fragile bones. 

Related Pearl: Radiological features of scurvy

Radiological features of scurvy:

  • Generalised osteopenia
  • Pencil-point cortex: Cortical thinning
  • Periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage
  • Scorbutic rosary: Expansion of the costochondral junctions
  • Hemarthrosis
  • Wimberger ring: Circular, opaque radiological shadow surrounding epiphyseal centers of ossification, which may result from bleeding
  • Frenkel line: Dense zone of provisional calcification 
  • Trummerfeld zone: Lucent metaphyseal band underlying Frankel line
  • Pelken spur: Metaphyseal spurs which result in cupping of the metaphysis

Related Pearl: Radiological features of rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is a cauliflower-like growth in the left eye along with leukocoria and an absent red reflex. The microscopic appearance of the specimen shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which is the causative gene in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and histology point toward a diagnosis of retinoblastoma which occurs due to a mutation in the Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Present within the first two years of life
  • Leukocoria 
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis.
  • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases.
  • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain is the investigation of choice.

 The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy. Enucleation is done when: 

  • Tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • Optic nerve is involved
  • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues resulting in marked proptosis. Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

Other options:

Option B: COL5A1 mutation affects type 5 collagen. This mutation is seen in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Option C: Retinitis pigmentosa occurs due to inherited or acquired mutations in the rhodopsin gene. 

Option D: NOTCH1 is the most commonly affected gene in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL).

questions.text: Which type of dysmenorrhea has cramping pain starting at the onset of menses and more pronounced in the first two days of menstruation?
questions.solution:
Cramping pain at the onset of menses and more pronounced in the first two days of menstruation is suggestive of spasmodic dysmenorrhea.

Dysmenorrhoea is defined as cramping pain accompanying menstruation.

It can be classified as:

A. Etiological:

  • Primary dysmenorrhoea: This is not associated with any identifiable pelvic pathology. It affects more than 50% of post-pubescent women in the age group of 18 to 25 years, with ovulatory cycles. This is due to excessive myometrial contraction, ischaemia, excessive prostaglandin production. It is associated with nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, and fatigue. Management includes reassurance, analgesics like NSAIDs, antispasmodics, and OC pills.
  • Secondary(Acquired) dysmenorrhoea: It is associated with the presence of organic pelvic pathologies such as fibroids, adenomyosis, PID, and endometriosis. It is associated with dyspareunia, infertility, and menstrual disorders. Treatment is directed to the cause

B.  Clinical:

  • Spasmodic dysmenorrhoea: It is the most prevalent and manifests as cramping pain, right before or at the start of the menstrual period, and is most pronounced on the first and second days of menstruation.
  • Congestive dysmenorrhoea: It presents as increasing pelvic discomfort and pelvic pain, a few days before menses begin. Thereafter, the patient experiences rapid relief of the symptoms. This variety is commonly seen in PID, IUCD users, varicosities of pelvic veins, pelvic endometriosis, and fibroids.
  • Membranous dysmenorrhoea: It is a special group, in which the endometrium is shed as a cast at the time of menstruation. The passage of the cast is associated with painful uterine cramps. It is the rarest variety.

questions.text: Which of the following is an advantage of using contact lenses over spectacles?
questions.solution:
Prismatic effects will be less in contact lenses as compared to spectacles.

In spectacles, the edge of the lens acts as a prism leading to prismatic effects. Due to the prismatic effect produced by the spectacles used in aphakia, patients can experience visual problems like roving-ring scotoma and jack-in-the-box phenomenon.

Contact lenses are artificial devices that act as a substitute for the anterior surface of the cornea. Contact lenses have multiple therapeutic uses. They include providing pain relief in bullous keratopathy by using soft bandage lenses as it protects the exposed corneal nerve endings from the eyelid's shearing forces during blinking.

Constant use can cause complications such as giant papillary conjunctivitis, superficial punctate keratitis, tight lens syndrome, and acute/chronic hypoxia.

Patients with regular use of contact lenses are at higher risk of infection leading to acanthamoeba keratitis. This occurs in soft contact lens users who wash their lenses with tap water

Inflammation can be a complication in contact lens users. A giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis, most commonly associated with contact lens wear. 

Contact lenses decrease corneal oxygen supply. The cornea obtains its O2 supply from the atmosphere. The use of contact lenses decreases the O2 supply from the atmosphere. Although dry eye is caused by wearing contact lenses, lenses made of hydrogel, which are high in water content are beneficial in dry eye.

Difficulties in the correction of aphakia by spectacles include the following:

  • Image magnification by 25–30%
  • Spherical aberrations producing a “pin cushion effect”
  • Roving-ring scotoma is seen in the correction of aphakia with spectacles due to prismatic effects at the edge of the lens.
  • Jack-in-the-box phenomenon from the prismatic effects at the edge of the lens
  • Reduced visual fields
  • Physical inconvenience

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA(polymethylmethacrylate). 
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA - hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty following a road accident. The patient is unconscious; the following image shows the CT scan. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The plain computed tomography (CT) scan shows a concave-convex shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of subdural hematoma.

An acute SDH is the result of the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. It is usually due to the rupture of bridging veins running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses. The level of consciousness is usually impaired at presentation and may deteriorate further as the hematoma expands. Elderly and alcoholic patients are at a higher risk of acute SDH formation after head trauma due to brain atrophy. On CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion.

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  • Thickness >1 cm
  • Midline shift >5 mm
  • Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score drops by two or more points from the time of injury to hospitalization.

Chronic subdural hematoma results from a hematoma that expands over days or weeks by osmosis, ultimately producing symptoms of raised ICP or focal deficits. On a CT scan, diffuse hypodensity overlying the brain surface would be seen as shown in the image below.

Related Pearl: Intracranial Hemorrhage (ICH)

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH): 

  • Source: Arterial bleed
  • MC- Middle meningeal artery 
  • Cause- Trauma 
  • Clinical features: Lucid interval is characteristic 
  • CT – Lentiform opacity 
  • Treatment: A large or rapidly evolving EDH requires surgical evacuation

 

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous bleed 
  • Bridging dural veins 
  • Causes: Trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, shaken baby syndrome 
  • Clinical features
    • Acute SDH: may be associated with lucid interval
    • Chronic SDH: drowsiness, headache
  • CT- crescentic opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

  • Source: Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – Trauma
    • 2nd MC – Rupture of berry aneurysm
  • MC sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery 
  • Clinical features: Thunderclap headache with neck stiffness +/- FND 
  • Investigations:
    • Non-contrast CT brain,
    • CSF xanthochromia (peaks in 2 days and subsides in 2 weeks) 
  • Treatment:
    • Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm,
    • Triple H therapy – hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution to prevent vasospasm 

 

Intraparenchymal hemorrhage- (MC type of ICH)

  • Source- Arterial bleed 
  • Causes:
    • MC – hypertension
    • Trauma, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, bleeding disorders, neoplasms, vascular malformations 
  • MC sites:
    • Putamen (basal ganglia)
    • Thalamus
    • Cerebellum
    • Pons 
  • Treatment:
    • Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP or fresh platelets as required
    • Surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoms >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 22 year old female  presents within 8 hours of having sexual intercourse and asking for emergency contraception.She says she doesn't want multiple pills and wants just one pill. What will be your advice?
questions.solution:
The patient asks for emergency contraception and the drug used is Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg.

Levonorgestrel (LNG):

Prostinar tablet contains 0.75 mg LNG. One tablet should be taken within 72 h of unprotected intercourse and another 12 h later. Alternately, two tablets can be taken as a single dose. The failure rate is 1.1%. The tablets can be offered up to 120 h but their efficacy decreases with the longer coital-drug interval. LNG prevents ovulation and causes desynchronization of endometrium through its receptors (luteal phase deficiency). The period may come earlier or be delayed.

Side effects are those of progestogens. The hormone is not teratogenic in case pregnancy does occur but the risk of ectopic pregnancy remains.

Advantages:

  • It has no estrogen and its associated side effects
  • It can be offered to hypertensive, cardiac, and diabetic women
  • It can be offered to a lactating woman
  • It can be given as late as 120 hours after the unprotected intercourse
  • Single-dose therapy is an advantage

Contraindicated in liver disease, contains lactate, and with an allergy to galactose. The drug is also contraindicated in a woman with a history of thrombophlebitis and migraine.  

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about carcinoid tumours of appendix?

choices.text: Size appears to be the best predictor of malignant behavior and metastatic potential
Arise from Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn
Most common location is the base of the appendix
Most common tumour of the appendix

questions.solution:
Most common location of carcinoid tumour of the appendix is the tip of appendix (i.e., the distal third of the appendix).

Carcinoid tumour:

  • Synonym – Argentaffinoma
  • It arises in argentaffin tissue (Kulchitsky cells of the crypts of Lieberkühn).
  • It is the most common tumour of the appendix
  • It is ten times more common than any other neoplasm of the appendix.
  • Most often, it presents with symptoms of subacute or recurrent appendicitis.
  • It is frequently found in the distal third (mostly tip) of the appendix.
  • Moderately hard, yellow tumor between the intact mucosa and the peritoneum.
  • Microscopically:
    • Tumour cells are small, arranged in small nests within the muscle, and have a characteristic pattern using immunohistochemical stain for chromogranin B
    • Carcinoid tumour of the appendix rarely gives rise to metastasis.

Treatment :

  • Appendicectomy has been shown to be sufficient treatment.
  • Indications for right hemicolectomy :
    • Involvement of the cecal wall
    • Tumour is 2 cm or more in size
    • Lymph nodes are involved

A 30-year-old male sustains thoracic spinal cord injury in a road accident and develops neurogenic shock. 
In this patient with neurogenic shock, hypotension will be associated with-
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock is associated with bradycardia and not tachycardia.

Features of Neurogenic shock:

  • Neurogenic shock is usually secondary to spinal cord injuries due to vertebral body fractures of the cervical or high thoracic region that disrupts the sympathetic outflow. 
  • Loss of vasoconstrictor impulses results in decreased peripheral resistance, decreased venous return and decreased cardiac output, resulting in shock.
  Hypovolemic Cardiogenic Obstructive Distributive

Vascular resistance High High High Low
Venous pressure Low High High Low
Mixed venous saturation Low Low Low High
Base deficit High High High High
Type of distributive shock Cause of vasodilation 
Septic shock Bacterial endotoxin and immune activation
Anaphylactic shock Histamine release
Neurogenic shock (spinal cord injury) Failure of sympathetic outflow

The classic description of neurogenic shock consists of:

  • Decreased blood pressure associated with bradycardia (absence of reflexive tachycardia due to disrupted sympathetic discharge).
  • Warm extremities (due to loss of peripheral vasoconstriction)
  • Motor and sensory deficits indicative of a spinal cord injury
  • Radiographic evidence of a vertebral fracture

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with history of dysphagia, halitosis and aspiration pneumonia. A barium swallow was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the collection of contrast in a pouch-like structure, which favours the diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum.

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum resulting from herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian triangle (or dehiscence of Killian), an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibres of the lower inferior constrictor (At the level of the hypopharynx, just proximal to the upper oesophagal sphincter). This phenomenon may lead to the creation of a sac with a narrow neck that can trap liquid and food. The distended sac may compress the cervical oesophagus.

Clinical presentation:         

The entrapment of liquid and/or food within the diverticulum may result in:

  • Globus sensation
  • Dysphagia
  • Halitosis
  • Regurgitation
  • Aspiration pneumonia

Diagnosis is by Barium swallow studies and video laryngoscopy.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: During a pre-operative consultation, a 32-year-old female patient expresses concerns about the type of anaesthesia for her upcoming surgery. She specifically asks about the differences between epidural and spinal anaesthesia. Which of the following is not true about epidural anaesthesia, in comparison to spinal anaesthesia?

choices.text: The density of the block is less
Less chances of post-dural puncture headache

questions.solution:
Epidural anaesthesia has a slower onset of action, as compared to spinal anaesthesia.

Epidural anaesthesia is a method of neuraxial pain control in which anaesthetic medications are injected into the epidural space to block sensory and motor spinal nerve roots in the thoracic, abdominal, pelvic, and lower extremity areas. 

Epidural techniques are widely used for surgical anaesthesia, obstetric analgesia, postoperative pain control (Option D), and chronic pain management.

In epidural anaesthesia, the needle does not penetrate the dura mater; hence, the chances of a post-dural puncture headache are low. (Option C) However, compared to spinal anesthesia, it has a slower onset of action and a low density (Option B) of the block. 

The image below is of the 18G Tuohy needle, which is the most common needle used in epidural anaesthesia.

 

The needle shaft is calibrated and has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that prevents accidental dural puncture. It is made from a flexible, radio-opaque plastic so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

questions.text: A patient with a fungal infection was started on amphotericin B. Within a few days he started complaining about decreased urine output. On examination, it revealed muddy brown casts in urine. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Muddy brown casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis which is a type of intrinsic renal failure. Epithelial casts and granular casts can also be seen in acute tubular necrosis.

Casts in Urine

  • Hyaline cast: Normal physiological conditions, fever, exercise, prerenal failure
  • RBC cast: Glomerular injury
  • WBC cast: Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis
  • Muddy-brown granular cast: Acute tubular necrosis
  • Broad cast: Chronic renal failure

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance
