questions.text: Whole-body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The whole-body CT of a trauma patient does not include CT limbs.

Whole-body CT or trauma CT or pans can is increasingly being used in the context of trauma patients with a dangerous mechanism of injury:

  1. Non-contrast CT of head
  2. Non-contrast CT of neck
  3. Contrast-enhanced CT of chest (arterial phase)
  4. Contrast-enhanced CT of abdomen (portal venous phase)

The purpose of the scan is to rapidly evaluate life-threatening injuries and accurately diagnose known and unknown injuries.

While limb injuries can certainly occur in trauma cases, they are usually assessed through physical examination, X-rays, or targeted CT scans if there is suspicion of a specific injury. Including limb imaging as part of the standard whole-body CT scan protocol would increase the scan time and radiation exposure for the patient without significantly impacting the detection of life-threatening injuries.

Therefore, CT limbs is the exception and is not typically included in the whole-body CT scan protocol for trauma patients.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of watering, redness, foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a severe form of mechanically induced papillary conjunctivitis. It is most commonly associated with contact lens wear. It can also be associated with ocular prostheses, exposed sutures, and scleral buckles.

The patients usually present with redness, foreign body sensation, increased mucus production, itching, blurring, and loss of contact lens tolerance. On examination, giant papillae are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae.

Papillae are reddish, flat-topped raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva These are the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium.

The image below shows papillae in the tarsal conjunctiva.

Treatment includes removing the offending cause. Mast cell stabilizers such as sodium cromoglycate, and drugs like azelastine and olopatadine which have combined antihistamine and mast cell stabilizing effects are effective. Steroids can be used for resistant cases.

Other options:

Option A - Trachoma is caused by chlamydia trachomatis. In acute trachoma, sago grain follicles are characteristically seen as shown below. 

Option B - Follicular conjunctivitis has follicles which are greyish-white raised areas seen on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses. The image is shown below.

Option D - In spring catarrh (vernal catarrh), cobblestone appearance is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva, ropy discharge, and Maxwell–Lyon sign are present. Horner-Tranta’s spots which are discrete whitish raised dots along the limbus can also be seen. It is more common during summer.

Image showing Horner-Tranta’s spots.

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

Strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (1–9 yrs)

  • Prevalence >10% → SAFE
  • 5 to 10% → FE
  • < 5% → NO intervention

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with complaints of fatigue which gets worse towards the end of the day. She also says that sometimes while watching television, she sees double. The physician suspects a case of myasthenia gravis. Which of the following tests has the highest sensitivity in the diagnosis of this condition?

choices.text: Acetylcholine receptor and muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase antibodies

questions.solution:
Single-fibre electromyography has the highest sensitivity in the clinical diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness. Females are more commonly affected than males, and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by muscle weakness and fatigability that worsen with repeated use or later in the day, often improving with rest or sleep. Limb weakness is typically proximal and asymmetrical, with early involvement of cranial muscles, particularly the extraocular and eyelid muscles, leading to diplopia and ptosis. Facial weakness may cause a characteristic snarling expression when smiling, and patients often experience difficulty in chewing, nasal speech due to palate and tongue weakness, and swallowing difficulties. Deep tendon reflexes remain intact. A myasthenic crisis, a severe exacerbation of muscle weakness affecting respiratory muscles, can lead to ventilatory failure, most commonly triggered by infections or excessive anticholinesterase medication use.

The tests used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis are:

  • Single-fibre electromyography (SFEMG) simultaneously records action potentials of two muscle fibers innervated by the same motor axon. The variability in time of the second action potential relative to the first is called "jitter" and this is increased in myasthenia gravis.
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered abnormal if there is a decremental response of >10%. 
  • The edrophonium ("Tensilon") test should be used for diagnosis only in those patients with obvious ptosis or ophthalmoparesis and is not confirmatory.
  • Testing for autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR-Ab) should be performed on all patients (most specific).
  • If the AChR-Abs test negative, an assay for antibodies against muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK) should be performed.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman who presented with vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and several episodes of vomiting was diagnosed with complete molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the following finding is seen in her left ovary. How would you proceed with the management of this patient?

choices.text: U/L oophorectomy with dilation and curettage

questions.solution:
This patient with a diagnosis of complete molar pregnancy and transvaginal ultrasonography showing the presence of multiple theca lutein cysts in the left ovary can be managed with just suction and curettage. Theca lutein cysts, usually regress spontaneously in a period of 2 to 4 months following evacuation of a molar pregnancy, hence can be managed expectantly. Sometimes,  it can undergo torsion and cause marked pelvic pain. In such instances, laparoscopic untwisting of such cysts has to be done.  

Irrespective of the size of the uterus, suction curettage is typically the preferred method for molar evacuation. If the cervix is minimally dilated, it is advisable to perform preoperative cervical dilation using an osmotic dilator. The amount of bleeding during surgery can be higher in cases of molar pregnancy compared to a uterus of similar size that contains nonmolar products. Having large moles necessitates the use of appropriate anesthetic, sufficient intravenous access, and availability of blood-banking services. To perform a molar evacuation, the cervix is mechanically dilated to facilitate the insertion of a large Karman suction cannula. A normal diameter of 10 to 14 mm is common, depending on the size of the uterus. Oxytocin is used during the evacuation process to minimize hemorrhage. Intraoperative sonography is frequently advised to guarantee thorough evacuation of the uterine cavity and reduce the risk of perforation. When the myometrium has contracted, a meticulous yet delicate curettage can be performed with a sharp large-loop Sims curette. The bleeding persists despite the removal of the uterus and the administration of oxytocin. In such cases, further uterotonic drugs are administered. In rare cases, pelvic arterial embolization, uterine packing, or hysterectomy may be required. 

Indications for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN

Note: Anti-D immunoglobulin to be given to Rh-negative women. The dose is 50 micrograms in the first trimester and 300 micrograms when gestational age is more than 12 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Oophorectomy is not indicated as the patient has no evidence of ovarian torsion on imaging as well as clinical assessment. Theca lutein cysts tend to spontaneously resolve following evacuation.

Option B: Labor-induced evacuation is very rarely performed owing to increased blood loss and the development of persistent trophoblastic disease.

Option D: Hysterectomy with B/L oophorectomy may be performed in patients who have completed their family along with signs of ovarian torsion due to large size cysts.

questions.text: In the experiment shown below, what role does the whistle play?
questions.solution:
The experiment shown in the image is that of classical conditioning by Ivan Pavlov. The whistle plays the role of a conditional stimulus.

Classical conditioning is the theory of learning where a neutral stimuli is associated with a psychologically significant event.

Events in the Pavlov experiment:

  • Food - Unconditional stimulus as it elicits salivation before the experiment commences
  • Response to food - Salivation as a result of the unconditional stimulus is the unconditional response as it is elicited before the commencement of the experiment.
  • Bell/Whistle - Conditional stimulus as it elicits salivation conditional to the pairing of the bell and food
  • Response to the bell/whistle - This is known as the conditional response as the dog has been conditioned to react to the conditional stimulus.

This model usually deals with involuntary responses. It is also called learning by association or respondent conditioning. He's also known for his work on the physiology of digestion

questions.text: A 53-year-old female patient presents with complaints of weakness for the last 2 months. Additionally, she is facing difficulty rising from a chair, and combing her hair every morning. A physical exam reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. Skin findings are as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette, this patient's symptoms along with the image findings showing heliotrope rash are highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis involves CD 4+ cells, perimyseal infiltrates, and is associated with underlying malignancy. 

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations. The pattern of muscle involvement helps distinguish a myopathy from a cerebral, spinal cord, neuronal or neuromuscular junction cause. It is commonly associated with an underlying malignancy.

Classic signs-

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- Confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- Linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- Mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- Accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin.

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids being the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required. 

Note: Inclusion Body myositis is resistant to immunosuppressive medication 

Muscle biopsy findings in various inflammatory myositis are as follows-

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida was taken up for emergency cesarean section due to failure of induction of labor and fetal distress.  The prophylactic antibiotic of choice before the cesarean section is___
questions.solution:
Cefazolin 1 gram is an efficacious and cost-effective choice for prophylaxis before cesarean section.

Cefazolin is commonly used for antibiotic prophylaxis before a cesarean section to reduce the risk of postoperative infections. A single dose of 1–2 g IV is administered within 60 minutes before surgical incision, with an additional dose if surgery lasts longer than 3 hours or there is excessive blood loss. If the patient has a high BMI (>30 kg/m²), a 3 g dose may be recommended for adequate coverage.

For obese women, a 2-g dose usually provides adequate coverage.

questions.text: A patient presented with palpitations and features of right heart failure. Family history is positive for sudden cardiac death in his brother. His ECG is given below. The marked changes in the image are described as:
questions.solution:
The changes marked in ECG show a notched deflection at the end of the QRS complex due to delayed ventricular activation known as an epsilon wave. It is commonly seen in patients with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC).

ARVC is autosomal dominant cardiomyopathy characterised by fibrofatty replacement in the myocardium of the ventricles. It most commonly affects the right ventricle. It is due to mutations in the gene encoding desmosome-associated protein plakophilin 2. This leads to defective cell-adhesion proteins in the desmosomes that link adjacent cardiac myocytes.

The patients usually present with rhythm disturbances, right-sided heart failure, and sudden cardiac death. ARVC is associated with Naxos syndrome. This syndrome is characterised by arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy and hyperkeratosis of the palmar and the plantar surfaces. 

Morphology shows severe thinning of the right ventricular wall due to loss of myocytes, accompanied by extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis. In ARVC, there is T inversion and delayed ventricular activation manifesting as epsilon waves.

Other options:

Option A: Delta wave is the slurred upstroke of the QRS complex as seen during ventricular pre-excitation, a feature of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. 

Option C: Osborn waves may be seen in the ECG of patients with systemic hypothermia, hypercalcemia, brain injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation, vasospastic angina, or idiopathic ventricular fibrillation. They are observed as a hump-like elevation at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment. An alteration in the ventricular transmural action potential is attributed to their appearance on an ECG.

Option D: Saw-tooth wave is seen in atrial flutter. It is caused due to repetitive atrial excitation caused by large re-entry impulses circulating within the atrial myocardium.

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is ______.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

Branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. It is usually lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate to a lesser extent when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing?
  1. Brainstem-evoked response audiometry
  2. Otoacoustic emissions
  3. Pure tone audiometry 
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA), otoacoustic emissions (OAE), and tympanometry are objective tests for hearing. 

The objective tests of hearing are:

  • Evoked response audiometry
    • Electrocochleography
    • Auditory brainstem response
  • Otoacoustic emissions
  • Impedance audiometry
    • Tympanometry
    • Acoustic reflex measurements

Objective tests in ENT are diagnostic procedures that provide measurable, examiner-independent results. 

Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA) or Auditory brainstem response (ABR) is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway. It elicits brainstem responses to auditory stimulation. Click stimuli or tone bursts lead to the generation of electrical potentials which are picked up from surface electrodes on the vertex.

Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) refer to an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea. It can be elicited by a microphone in the external auditory canal and is then analyzed by a computer. They test the function of the cochlea. They are used to test hearing in neonates, and sedated/unconscious patients, and to differentiate cochlear from retro-cochlear hearing loss. 

Tympanometry is a component of impedance audiometry. It is an objective test of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the tympanic membrane, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure differentials applied from the external ear is measured. This is plotted on a graph, to obtain a tympanogram. 

Note- Pure tone audiometry is a subjective test for hearing as it relies on the patient's responses to pure tone stimuli. Other examples of subjective tests include:

  • Tuning fork tests
  • Speech audiometry

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI – inferior colliculus
  • Wave VII - medial geniculate body

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

Related Pearl: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

  • Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.
  • Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

  • Best audiometric test for screening in neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.
  • Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.
  • Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee and ankle joint for one week with the following lesions on his soles. He gives a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. Which of the following is not commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with arthritis, preceding gastrointestinal infection and the above image showing keratoderma blennorrhagica are suggestive of reactive arthritis/Reiter's syndrome. Posterior uveitis is not seen in this condition. Instead, anterior uveitis is seen. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) comes under the spectrum of seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is an acute asymmetric nonpurulent arthritis precipitated by an antecedent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. It usually occurs in young men and chronic ReA is associated with HLA-B27. Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Chlamydia trachomatis, Clostridium difficile, certain toxigenic Escherichia coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, and Mycoplasma genitalium. There is a typical antecedent history of infection 1-4 weeks before the onset of arthritic symptoms.

Clinical features of ReA include constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue and weight loss. There may be asymmetric arthritis with the involvement of a new joint within a few days. It involves large weight-bearing joints like knee and ankle. Dactylitis/sausage digit is a distinctive feature of reactive and psoriatic arthritis.

Extraarticular manifestations include keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles, enthesitis (option C), anterior uveitis, and conjunctivitis (option A). Circinate balanitis (option B) which consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis can be seen. Genitourinary symptoms like urethritis and prostatitis may occur. Cardiac conduction defects and aortic regurgitation may rarely occur.

Elevated ESR and CRP can be seen during the acute phase. Joint X-rays show juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, loss of joint space, periostitis with new bone formation, and comma-shaped syndesmophytes.

High-dose NSAIDs have been shown to have some degree of benefit. Antibiotics during the antecedent infection may prevent the emergence of ReA. Intralesional glucocorticoids have been shown to benefit tendinitis and other enthesitic lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following maneuver is shown in the image below
questions.solution:
• The above image shows Pinard’s Maneuver which is used in the management of frank breech.
  • The Pinard maneuver may be needed with a frank breech to facilitate delivery of the legs, only after the fetal umbilicus has been reached. Pressure is exerted against the inner aspect of the knee. Flexion of the knee follows, and the lower leg is swept medially and out of the vagina.

Pinard’s maneuver:

  • Patient should be under general anaesthesia.
  • The palmer surface of obstetrician is to be introduce facing the ventral surface of foetus.
  • Breech is pushed up at least to the level of symphysis pubis.
  • Middle and index fingers should apply pressure in popliteal fossa and abduction of the fossa done, which causes partial flexion of leg.
  • Head is flexed by other hand abdominally i.e. externally.
  • The foot is brought down by grasping at the ankle by internal fingers.
  • Other leg is brought down in the same manner.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Loveset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A 32-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with oral ulcers and a burning sensation in his oral cavity. A picture of the oral cavity is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario of a 32-year-old chronic alcoholic with oral ulcers and a burning sensation and the image showing white lesions on the oral cavity is leukoplakia. 

Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity characterized by whitish patches or plaques that cannot be rubbed off.  

They appear as small, well-circumscribed lesions and can extensively involve a large area of the oral mucosa.

Variants of leukoplakia are

  • Speckled leukoplakia is whitish lesions on an erythematous base. They have the highest risk of malignant transformation. 
  • Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia is rare and has a high risk for malignant transformation.

Management includes smoking cessation and reduction in alcohol consumption. A biopsy should be done and a photographic record of the lesion is used for follow-up.

Other premalignant conditions of the oral cavity are erythroplakia and oral submucosal fibrosis.

Other Options:

Option B:  Erythroplakia ( refers to irregular, reddish velvety plaques on the oral cavity. The surface may be nodular and may bleed. It has a high risk of malignant transformation. Biopsy should be done followed by surgical ablation.

Option C: Oral submucosal fibrosis  is characterized by the formation of fibrous bands beneath the oral cavity. The disease is progressive and causes limitation of mouth opening and restricted tongue movements. Intralesional steroids and surgical excision of fibrous bands are recommended. 

Option D: Malakoplakia  is a rare inflammatory condition affecting immunocompromised individuals. It mainly affects the urinary tract but can involve any organ system. The clinical presentation includes tender ulcerations, nodules, papules, and plaques or fungating masses with perianal and genital skin involvement. Systemic antibiotics and surgical excision are recommended.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness, and reduced muscle stretch reflexes, associated with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given image showing muscle atrophy, high arch of foot, and hammer-toes which, along with the other clinical features mentioned above, are suggestive of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. CMT is a syndrome of many genetically distinct disorders.

CMT type 1 is the most common form of hereditary neuropathy. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop. The following findings are seen:

  • No numbness or tingling
  • Reduced sensation to all modalities apparent on examination
  • Reduced muscle stretch reflexes
  • Atrophy of the muscles below the knee, leading to inverted champagne bottle legs 

Diabetic neuropathy, primary amyloidosis, neuropathy associated with Sjogren’s syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis are acquired forms of neuropathies.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum's disease is a hereditary disorder of lipid metabolism. They can manifest in infancy to early adulthood with classic tetrad of:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Cerebellar ataxia
  • Elevated CSF protein concentration

They have elevated serum phytanic acid and they are autosomal recessive in nature. 

Option C- Sjogren syndrome is a chronic, slowly progressing autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. Predominately seen in middle-aged women. Majority of them present with impaired lacrimal and salivary gland function. Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome is either sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy like mononeuritis multiplex and myelitis

Option D- Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. The incidence increases between the age of 25 to 55 years. Chronic inflammation of ankle and midtarsal regions leads to pes planovalgus or flat feet. Other deformities seen in RA are: 

  • Swan-neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity
  • Z-line deformity

questions.text: While performing an inguinal hernia repair in a 3-year-old boy, you notice Meckel’s diverticulum as the content of the hernial sac. What is this hernia called?
questions.solution:
Meckel’s diverticulum found in inguinal or femoral hernial sacs is known as Littre's hernia. It can cause intestinal obstruction.

Option A: Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option B: Narath’s hernia is seen in patients with congenital dislocation of the hip. It is a femoral hernia seen behind the femoral vessels.

Option C: Cloquet’s hernia is a type of femoral hernia where the sac lies under the pectineus fascia.

questions.text: A young female patient with a history of several episodes of bipolar disorder is brought to the emergency ward after she was found in a state of distress with several empty bottles of her medication. On examination, she appears confused, and agitated and has coarse tremors, ataxia, and hyperreflexia. Which of the following drugs is likely to have caused her symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of bipolar disorder along with central nervous symptoms such as confusion, agitation, coarse tremors, ataxia, and hyperreflexia point toward a possible diagnosis of lithium toxicity.

Lithium is a mood stabilizer that is used in the treatment of acute mania and bipolar disorder.

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index and hence frequent monitoring of serum lithium concentration is necessary for patients who are on lithium therapy.

0.5-0.8 mEq/L is considered ideal for maintenance therapy in patients with bipolar disorder whereas a serum lithium concentration of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L is required in patients with episodes of acute mania.

Initially, lithium toxicity presents with symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, mild diarrhea, and fine tremors. Nervous system toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, ataxia, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy

Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L

  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use

  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A young woman has a fear of getting into elevators since birth. She prefers stairs over elevators. She is also scared to use public transport. What is this condition known as?
questions.solution:
This woman with a fear of elevators and public transport, but prefers stairs over elevators from where she can escape easily has agoraphobia.

Agoraphobia is the anxiety that occurs when one is in a public or crowded place, from which a potential escape is difficult, or help may not be readily available. example crowds, public places, or public transportation.

It is more common in women. It leads to severe restrictions on the individual’s travel and daily routine.

Option A: Claustrophobia - Fear of closed spaces

Option B: Aerophobia - Fear of flying 

Option D: Ailurophobia - Fear of cats

Note: Specific phobia is the most common type of phobia. Agoraphobia is not a specific phobia and is classified separately under anxiety disorders.

Some special terms:

  • Acrophobia: Fear of heights
  • Agoraphobia: Fear of the places from where easy escape is not possible
  • Xenophobia: fear of strangers
  • Zoophobia: fear of animals
  • Claustrophobia: fear of closed spaces

questions.text: Identify the given condition:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a port wine stain.

Port wine stains are congenital lesions that may occur anywhere in the body. Visually they appear as partially or completely blanchable, pink to red or reddish brown patches. It is a low-flow vascular malformation.

Commonly they occur as isolated skin lesions but in rare cases, they are part of certain complex syndromes.

This lesion is associated with syndromes such as Sturge-Weber syndrome and occult spinal dysraphism. Port-wine stain occurring in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve is associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

Features of port wine stain:

  • It does not fade with time
  • Special form of nevus flammeus
  • Tends to grow during childhood
  • Thicken the skin surface

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a severe neurocutaneous disorder. Patients have a capillary malformation on the face and brain (leptomeninges) and abnormal eye blood vessels leading to glaucoma. The capillary malformation or port wine stain appears as a homogenous, pink, red, or purple macule, present at birth. Most children with intracranial vascular anomalies present with seizures before the age of two. Patients also may have hemiparesis, stroke-like episodes, headaches, and developmental delay.

Treatment of the cutaneous vascular lesion can be done by a pulsed-dye laser. Seizures and glaucoma should also be treated.

Option A: Lisch nodules are small well-defined nodules that are seen in neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface as shown in the image below.

Option C: Infantile hemangioma is a common benign vascular tumour in childhood. It presents anywhere on the body and is usually not present at birth. They appear red or maroon if superficial, and bluish if deep. They regress by 4 years of age usually. It is shown in the image below. 

Option D: Café-au-lait macules are flat, pigmented skin patches with a light brown colour, resembling coffee with milk. They can be a normal variation or associated with conditions like neurofibromatosis type 1.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with past history of hypertension, diabetes and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and vomiting. The patient is noted to be agitated, her blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg. Ophthalmoscopic examination shows the presence of papilledema. The antihypertensive which is least useful in the management of hypertension in this scenario is _______
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of the presence of agitated behaviour, elevated blood pressure, and papilledema points towards the diagnosis of malignant hypertension. The drug that is least useful in the management is diuretics (furosemide).

Volume depletion is common in patients with malignant hypertension, and the administration of a diuretic together with a hypertensive agent can lead to an extreme drop in blood pressure. Also due to their delayed action, they are ineffective in hypertensive emergency cases requiring rapid BP reduction.

They are used only in conditions of volume overload such as acute pulmonary edema.

Other options:

Option B: Nicardipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina by relaxing blood vessels and improving blood flow. It is commonly administered intravenously in acute settings like hypertensive emergencies.

Option C: Labetalol is a combined alpha and beta-blocker used to treat hypertension, including in pregnancy and hypertensive emergencies. It lowers blood pressure by reducing heart rate and relaxing blood vessels.

Option D: Enalaprilat is the active intravenous form of enalapril, an ACE inhibitor used for managing acute hypertension. It works by inhibiting angiotensin-converting enzyme, leading to vasodilation and reduced blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the signs and symptoms of the condition represented below?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals enlarged adenoids, indicating a diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Patients present with a flattened or absent nasolabial fold, not a prominent one.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

Treatment of adenoid hypertrophy follows both medical and surgical approaches. Medical management includes antibiotics for acute infections, antiallergic measures, and nasal decongestants. However, adenoidectomy remains the definitive treatment when medical management fails or in cases with persistent symptoms.

The surgical indications include:

  • Chronic nasal obstruction
  • Chronic mouth breathing
  • Recurrent otitis media
  • Sleep apnea
  • Failure to thrive

questions.text:
A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient.

Na+: 145 mEq/L

K+: 4 mEq/L

Cl-: 90 mEq/L

HCO3-: 20 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The anion gap in this patient is 35 mEq/L. 

The anion gap is calculated as Na+ – [Cl- + HCO3-]. In this patient, the anion gap will be calculated as: 145 – (90 + 20) = 145 – 110 = 35 mEq/L.

Anion gap is representative of unmeasured anions which are normally present in the plasma, such as anionic proteins (albumin), phosphate, sulfate, and organic anions. When acid anions such as acetoacetate and lactate accumulate in the extracellular fluid, the anion gap increases, causing a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. A decrease in anion gap can occur due to an increase in abnormal cations (such as lithium, immunoglobulins), reduction in plasma albumin (nephrotic syndrome) or hyperviscosity and hyperlipidemia.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: If used early reduces cardiac output
Delayed clamping should be avoided in Rh- pregnancy
It is to be removed 48 hours after birth
Increases iron stores in the baby

questions.solution:
The given image shows an umbilical cord clamp. It should be kept in place until it falls off with the detached stump of the umbilical cord.

It is made of plastic and supplied in a sterile pack. It occludes the umbilical vessels effectively. In preterm infants, delayed clamping may improve transitional circulation, establish better red blood cell volume, reduce the need for blood transfusion and reduce the risk of necrotizing enterocolitis and intraventricular haemorrhage. It should be delayed by 30-60 seconds after birth.

Other options:

Option A: If performed early reduces cardiac output owing to reduced preload to the left ventricle whereas if performed late permits sufficient aeration of the lung and improved / smoother transitioning to a better cardiac output.

Option B: Early cord clamping is advised in Rh-negative pregnancy, babies with asphyxia, or infants of diabetic mothers. Early clamping can also reduce the need for phototherapy due to hyperbilirubinemia. 

Option D: Delayed umbilical cord clamping in term infants will increase haemoglobin levels at birth and improve iron stores for the first few months. This may have a favourable effect on developmental outcomes.

questions.text: An elderly man who is a known case of laryngeal carcinoma is brought to the hospital with severe dyspnea and stridor. The patient suddenly desaturates and you decide to perform a tracheostomy. Which of the following would you prefer for this patient?

choices.text: Low tracheostomy, done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
Mid tracheostomy, done through the 3rd  tracheal ring
High tracheostomy, done through the 2nd tracheal ring
High tracheostomy, done through the 1st tracheal ring

questions.solution:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

High tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (Isthmus lies against II, III, and IV tracheal ring). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

Functions: 

  • Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  • Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  • Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

The image shows a tracheostomy tube.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida with twin gestation presents to the clinic in active labor. The first baby is in breech presentation and the second baby is in cephalic presentation. What is the best step of management in this condition?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, since the first twin is in breech (non-cephalic presentation), the best step of management is to deliver through cesarean section.

Scheme of management of twins in labor:

  1. If the first twin/ both twins are in the non-cephalic presentation: deliver through cesarean section.
  2. If the first twin is in vertex presentation: Deliver the first twin through vaginal delivery and do not give methergine post-delivery of the first baby. Delivering the second twin, If it is in,
  • Breech: Deliver through breech extraction
  • Transverse lie
    • If the obstetrician is skilled in podalic version: Internal podalic version and breech extraction under GA. 
    • If the obstetrician is unskilled: External version into a longitudinal lie preferably cephalic or if that fails podalic. 
  • Vertex: Vaginal delivery, assisted forceps/ventouse.

Cesarean delivery of the breech fetus is indicated in the following:

  • Twins, with the first baby in the breech
  • Large fetus: >3800 to 4000 g
  • Apparently healthy and viable preterm fetus either with active labor or with indicated delivery
  • Severe IUGR
  • Footling presentation (due to risk of cord prolapse)
  • Hyperextended head
  • Contracted pelvis
  • Prior cesarean delivery
  • Preterm breech

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

Basic life support involves early recognition and management of emergencies such as heart attack, stroke, and foreign body airway obstruction. The sequence of BLS is circulation (chest compression), airway, and then breathing.

The airway is usually obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead applying pressure to tilt the head back. Simultaneously, the chin is lifted with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. This causes cervical flexion with an atlantooccipital extension (sniffing position). This lifts the tongue from the back of the throat.

Head-tilt chin-lift should not be performed in a patient with suspected cervical injury.

Other options: 

Option B: Jaw thrust- Both hands of the clinician are placed on either side of the patient’s head and the angles of the jaw are grasped and lifted. It can be performed in a patient with cervical injury but caution must be followed to not hyperextend the neck.

 

Option D: Manual inline stabilization is a maneuver that limits external head and neck movement in patients with cervical spine injuries. Fingers and palms of both hands are used to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to ensure successful airway intervention.

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: Photostress test is used to differentiate between _______.
questions.solution:
Photostress test is used to differentiate between diseases involving the macula and those involving the optic nerve.

In this test, one eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on the near chart. A bright light is then shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again; the time taken to recover is noted. The test is repeated with the other eye.

In normal persons and in patients with optic nerve disease, the recovery time is not affected. However, in patients with macular disease, the recovery time is prolonged and is usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time. This is because, in macular disease, the photoreceptors are damaged, and there is a delay in the visual pigment regeneration process.

questions.text: During ward rounds, a resident doctor inserts an intravenous cannula in the patient's hand as shown in the image. What is the gauge size of this cannula?

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presented to the emergency room with loss of consciousness, chest pain, and diaphoresis. On examination, she was grossly unstable and the bilateral pulses were unequal. ECG showed nonspecific ST-T changes. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation with acute onset chest pain, loss of consciousness and diaphoresis with bilaterally unequal pulses and ECG showing nonspecific ST-T changes is suggestive of aortic dissection, and as the patient is hemodynamically unstable, the next best investigation is transesophageal ECHO.

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta. Predisposing factors include mainly age, hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and pregnancy. The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Contrast-enhanced CT(CECT) is currently the most preferred imaging modality for aortic dissection. A double-lumen aorta is seen on CECT. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred for patients who are unstable for transportation.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system, which uses the location of the proximal tear alone.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with post-menopausal bleeding. Ultrasonography revealed a mass with feeding vessel as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Visualisation of a feeding vessel on ultrasonography is characteristic of an endometrial polyp.

Ultrasonography shows endometrial polyps, which are homogeneous, isoechoic to and continuous with the endometrium and preserve the endometrial interface. They may be centrally cystic, corresponding to dilated, fluid-filled glands. Colour Doppler usually reveals a characteristic feeding vessel.

 Benign endometrial polyps commonly occur at all ages, with their greatest prevalence after age 50. They are a common cause of postmenopausal bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: A fibroid uterus refers to the presence of benign tumors (fibroids) in the uterine wall, which can cause symptoms like heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and infertility. Treatment options include medication, minimally invasive procedures, or surgery, depending on severity.

Option C: Endometrial carcinoma is a cancer of the uterine lining, commonly presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, especially postmenopause. Early diagnosis through biopsy and imaging improves treatment outcomes, which may include surgery, radiation, or chemotherapy.

Option D: Leiomyosarcoma is a rare and aggressive malignant tumor arising from smooth muscle, commonly affecting the uterus or soft tissues. Treatment typically involves surgical removal, often combined with chemotherapy or radiation for advanced cases.

questions.text: A woman presents with amenorrhea, agalactorrhea, and fatigue 12 months post childbirth. She has dry skin and hair and decreased libido. Her MRI is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
This patient with amenorrhea, agalactorrhea and fatigue 12 months after childbirth with MRI showing pituitary necrosis, likely has Sheehan syndrome (Ischemic pituitary necrosis). The most appropriate treatment for this patient is hormone replacement therapy; 

The goal of management in Sheehan syndrome is to replace the deficient pituitary hormones. This is typically done with a combination of hydrocortisone, levothyroxine, and oxytocin. Sheehan syndrome is due to pituitary infarction consequent to traumatic major blood loss after child birth.

The pituitary undergoes hyperplastic enlargement during pregnancy, which increases the risk of haemorrhage and infarction.

The most prominent symptoms are the inability to nurse (lactational failure) due to absent prolactin secretion and postpartum amenorrhea due to absent FSH and LH secretion.

Patients affected may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoglycemia due to secondary adrenal insufficiency. Cortisol levels are affected leading to hypovolemia, hypoglycemia, and hyponatremia. Aldosterone is unaffected, and there is no salt wasting. Adrenal insufficiency is the most life-threatening complication. Hence, the first hormone to be replaced is glucocorticoids. 

Other options: 

Option B: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acromegaly.

Option C: Bromocriptine is a dopamine receptor analogue used for the management of lactorrhea seen in a functional prolactinoma. 

Option D: Pituitary resection is appropriate for craniopharyngiomas, benign tumours derived from Rathke’s pouch, a diverticulum arising from the embryonic buccal cavity, from which the anterior pituitary gland develops. It is most commonly seen in children (5–15 years); however, it exhibits a bimodal incidence and can also be seen in adults (55–65 years). Patients present with features of raised intracranial pressure, visual impairment in the form of bitemporal hemianopia and endocrinologic abnormalities, such as growth failure, hypothyroidism, diabetes insipidus, and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypo-function. MRI shows calcified cystic masses in the supra-sellar region.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is brought with 2nd degree burns involving the anterior aspect of both his lower limbs and the perineal region. According to the rule of 9, what is the BSA involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
19% of the body surface area (BSA) is involved in this patient. The anterior part of each lower limb, according to Wallace’s rule of 9, would be 9% each, and the perineum is considered to be 1% of the total BSA.

Rule of nines (Wallace): It divides the body into segments that are approximately 9% or multiples of 9%, with the perineum forming the remaining 1%. Because of the proportionately larger heads and smaller legs of infants and children, this method must be modified in a pediatric burn injury.

Note: Although Wallace’s rule of nines is more commonly used, the Lund and Browder chart is the most accurate in measuring the percentage of BSA affected in children and overall.

questions.text: Identify the given drain.
questions.solution:
The Romo Vac drain, depicted in the image, is a closed suction drain commonly used after mastectomy.

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely collect the air or fluids that may accumulate. This enhances wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains are prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries. Drains can be -

  • Open - They are based on the principle of gravity 
  • Semi-open - Their action is based on capillary effect
  • Closed - They carry out their actions through suction

Suction drains are commonly used in chest, breast, abdominal, thyroid, and plastic surgeries. They remove intraperitoneal secretions, anastomotic leaks, and blood from hemorrhage at the surgical site. Romo Vac drain is a negative suction drain closed drain kept in the subcutaneous tissue. Romo Vac drain is indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. 

Special types of drains:

  • Chest drains (option A) are connected to an underwater seal to aid the exit of air from the pleural cavity. They are used in pneumothorax, pleural effusion, and hemothorax. 
  • After surgical exploration of the bile duct, the sphincter of Oddi goes into spasm. To facilitate drainage of bile, a T tube may be used. 

Drain insertion site care: The site of insertion of the drain is kept clean by drying and patting the drain insertion site with a clean towel after bath. The dressing is changed daily with folded gauze pieces placed below and above the drain site. 

Removal of drains: The catheter at the site is milked for residual collections. It is then clamped and the suture holding the catheter is cut. The tube is then gently pulled out and any clots at the perforation end are removed. The time of removal of drains for various conditions is given below. 

  • Drains used in surgeries like thyroidectomy are usually removed within 24 hours. Their main purpose is to cover postoperative bleeding. 
  • In a mastectomy, a drain is placed for 5 days to collect serous collections.
  • Drains used to cover the colorectal anastomoses are placed for 5-7 days.
  • Common bile duct T-tube drains are usually placed for 10 days.
  • Drains for infections are removed when the infection subsides or when the content of the drain is minimal.

After the drain is removed, a folded gauze is placed over the drain insertion area. The dressing can be removed after 24 hours. The patient may be given an antibiotic ointment to apply over the area for a week.

Other options:

Option A: The following image shows an underwater seal drain.

Option C: Nelaton drain/catheter is commonly used as an intermittent urinary catheter. Like other intermittent catheters, it is also attached temporarily for draining the bladder and then removed. 

Option D: A Penrose drain is a flexible, soft, latex tube that's used to drain fluid from a surgical site after surgery. It's a type of passive drain.
